input: Intermittent core network resets causing temporary loss of 5G service (e.g.; AMF restarts visible);A core network software instability  possibly a bug or memory leak in the AMF or related function that triggers a crash/restart after running for some time. Each restart would drop active signaling connections; forcing UEs to re-register
output: Investigate core dump logs or error reports from the AMF around the time of resets. Engage the vendor for any known issues; apply a software patch or update that addresses the crash. As a mitigation; ensure redundant AMF nodes can pick up sessions (so a single AMF restart doesn t impact all users). After patching; monitor the uptime of the AMF and the continuity of user registrations to ensure the issue is resolved

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UE can register to 5G but fails to establish a PDU session for data (gets a rejection for data connection);The SMF is rejecting the PDU session setup. This could happen if the requested data network name (DNN/APN) or slice is not permitted for that UE; or if the network doesn t support the requested PDU session type (IPv6 vs IPv4; etc.). It might also be due to missing default route in core for that APN
output: Check the reject cause for the PDU Session in the signaling trace. If it s an Unknown or missing DNN or Slice not available; update the subscriber s allowed DNN/slice list in the UDM subscription data. If it s an unsupported request (like IPv6 PDP and network only has IPv4 addresses); adjust the allowed PDU types or configure dual-stack support. Implement the necessary configuration changes and then attempt the PDU session setup again; verifying that the UE can now establish a data session successfully

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Users in the same cell have different throughput; and it s traced to differences in core handling;Possibly some users are being routed via a different slice or APN with a capped bandwidth in the core network. A provisioning inconsistency might have placed a subset of users in a restricted QoS category; causing lower throughput for them irrespective of cell conditions
output: Audit the provisioning of the users experiencing lower throughput. Check their subscription profile and slice/APN assignment. If they re incorrectly assigned to a restricted profile or slice; update their subscription to match the intended service level. Also verify PCF rules to ensure no unintended throttling is applied. After re-provisioning; monitor those users (or test with one of their SIMs) to see if throughput now aligns with others in the same cell under similar conditions

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G users observe that browsing and apps work; but initial connection setup (DNS lookups) are slow;The DNS server provided to 5G users might be responding slowly. It could be overloaded; or the UPF is forwarding DNS queries to a distant server. Alternatively; there might be a delay in the DNS queries passing through the core network
output: Check what DNS server IP is assigned to the UEs (via DHCP or NAS). Test the response time of that DNS. If high latency; consider using a more local DNS resolver or deploying a caching DNS in the core or at the UPF. Also ensure multiple DNS servers are configured for redundancy. Implement the changes by updating the DHCP options or UDM profile for UEs; then test again by resolving a common hostname from a UE to confirm quicker DNS response times

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: After a core network software upgrade; some UEs did not reconnect automatically until hours later or after a reboot;Stale context issue: The upgrade might have reset or lost the context of those UEs without notifying them; leaving them in a limbo state. The core might think they re still connected (so it doesn t page them) while the UE thinks it s detached (or vice versa). This mismatch prevents immediate reconnection
output: On noticing the issue; perform a forced detach for the affected UEs from the core side (purge their old sessions in AMF/SMF) so that they are free to reconnect. Alternatively; instruct those users to toggle airplane mode or reboot to trigger a fresh registration. For future upgrades; use a make-before-break strategy or send detach messages to UEs before shutting down to avoid this scenario. Monitor the network post-upgrade to ensure all UEs reconnect properly and no one is left stranded

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G standalone UEs are unable to perform fallback to 4G for voice calls; resulting in call failure (and maybe data interruption);EPS Fallback or RAT fallback for voice (from 5G to 4G) is not configured correctly in the core or not supported by the UE. The UE attempts to place a voice call; the network should move it to LTE (since maybe VoNR is not available); but that procedure fails; dropping the call and potentially the data session
output: Verify that EPS Fallback is configured in the 5G core (AMF) and that the UE s subscription allows for it. Ensure the 5G cells are broadcasting the appropriate indicators for voice fallback. If the UE doesn't support VoNR; the network should trigger a handover to LTE for the call. Configure the necessary policies and test with an affected UE by initiating a voice call. The expected outcome is the UE switches to LTE and the call succeeds. Also confirm data continuity if possible during that switch

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G devices are unable to register on the network (no 5G service at all in the area);An issue in the 5G core s access management  for example; the AMF (Access and Mobility Management Function) might be down or overloaded; preventing new registrations. Alternatively; the 5G signaling between gNB and core (NG interface) is disrupted; so registration requests aren t being processed
output: Check the core network status; especially the AMF handling that area: look for alarms or high CPU load. If the AMF is unresponsive; fail over to a redundant instance or restart the service. Also verify the NG-C signaling link from gNB to AMF (NGAP) is intact (no SCTP failures). After restoring the AMF or signaling link; test with a UE to ensure it can register and obtain service

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UEs attach to 5G but cannot establish any data sessions (no internet access after registering);A Session Management Function (SMF) or User Plane Function (UPF) fault. The control plane (AMF) allows attach; but the SMF fails to create a PDU session or the UPF tunnel is not set up; so the user gets no data. Possibly the UPF is down or the SMF configuration for default data session is incorrect
output: Examine the core network logs for PDU Session Establishment procedures. Check if the SMF is responding to the UE s session request and if it allocates an IP. If the SMF is erroring out; restart or failover the SMF. If IP allocation or UPF setup failed; ensure the UPF is reachable and healthy (restart if needed). Once the SMF/UPF issue is resolved; verify that a UE can establish a data session and pass traffic after attach

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G data sessions drop or reset after a fixed time (e.g.; every 30 minutes) for multiple users;A core network timer or software bug is causing session teardown. For instance; an idle timeout or session lifetime in the SMF/UPF might be misconfigured; or a NAT timeout in the network is closing connections; leading to session resets
output: Identify if there's a common timing to the drop (check SMF session logs for a pattern). If an idle timer is too short; increase it to accommodate typical usage. Check any NAT device for connection timeouts and adjust to match 5G session needs. Also look for known bugs in the SMF software regarding session duration and apply patches. After adjustments; monitor new sessions to ensure they persist as expected without unexpected drops

output: Review the UPF deployment and the configuration for UPF selection (NSSF rules or SMF logic). Ensure that for the affected region; a local UPF is available and properly registered; and that the subscriber/slice is configured to use it. output: Check the configured IP pools for the APN or Data Network in the core network. Determine if the pool is depleted; if so; extend the pool or add a new IP range. input: All users on a particular network slice have lost connectivity; while other slices are unaffected;A slice-specific core network failure. For instance; the network functions dedicated to that slice (like a slice-specific SMF/UPF or a slice-specific authentication server) may have crashed or become unreachable; isolating that slice s users

Ensure the slice s NSSAI configurations are intact and that the NSSF is directing slice traffic correctly. For example; if the subscribers are not authorized for the requested slice or APN; the core might instantly drop the session after setup

If it s a network error; check for recent configuration changes in SMF/PCF regarding allowed services. Rectify the policy or subscription mismatch so that legitimate sessions are not erroneously dropped. Test by initiating data sessions for an affected user to ensure the connection now remains up

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Core network logs show numerous error messages and some 5G traffic is getting delayed or retransmitted;A misconfiguration or incompatibility on a core interface (such as NGAP between gNB and AMF or GTP-U between gNB and UPF) is causing errors. For instance; an MTU mismatch could lead to fragmentation issues; or a version mismatch in protocols causing errors that necessitate retries
output: Identify the specific error in the core logs (e.g.; NGAP message parse errors or GTP-U packet drops). If it s MTU related; adjust the MTU settings on the gNB and core interfaces to a common value and ensure path MTU discovery is enabled. If it s a protocol/version issue; ensure all network functions and gNBs are on compatible software releases and configurations. After resolving the mismatch; monitor to see that errors in logs subside and user-plane traffic flows without unusual delays or retries

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Sudden increase in user-plane latency for 5G users without any radio or backhaul alarms;The UPF (user plane function) handling the traffic might be experiencing high load or internal issues; causing slow packet processing. It could also be that traffic got rerouted through a less optimal UPF or a debug feature (like trace) was left enabled; adding latency
output: Check the UPF performance metrics (CPU; processing queue lengths). If overloaded; consider scaling out with additional UPF instances and load-balancing sessions. Ensure no unnecessary packet inspection or tracing is active on the UPF. Also verify if a recent change caused traffic to shift to a UPF in a farther location. After addressing (like adding more UPF capacity or fixing route); measure end-to-end latency (e.g.; using ping/ traceroute from a UE) to confirm it has returned to normal levels

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Intermittent core network resets causing temporary loss of 5G service (e.g.; AMF restarts visible);A core network software instability  possibly a bug or memory leak in the AMF or related function that triggers a crash/restart after running for some time. Each restart would drop active signaling connections; forcing UEs to re-register
output: Investigate core dump logs or error reports from the AMF around the time of resets. Engage the vendor for any known issues; apply a software patch or update that addresses the crash. As a mitigation; ensure redundant AMF nodes can pick up sessions (so a single AMF restart doesn t impact all users). After patching; monitor the uptime of the AMF and the continuity of user registrations to ensure the issue is resolved

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UE can register to 5G but fails to establish a PDU session for data (gets a rejection for data connection);The SMF is rejecting the PDU session setup. This could happen if the requested data network name (DNN/APN) or slice is not permitted for that UE; or if the network doesn t support the requested PDU session type (IPv6 vs IPv4; etc.). It might also be due to missing default route in core for that APN
output: Check the reject cause for the PDU Session in the signaling trace. If it s an Unknown or missing DNN or Slice not available; update the subscriber s allowed DNN/slice list in the UDM subscription data. If it s an unsupported request (like IPv6 PDP and network only has IPv4 addresses); ensure the core and UPF support the type (enable IPv6 support if needed or configure dual-stack). Implement the necessary configuration changes and then attempt the PDU session setup again; verifying that the UE can now establish a data session successfully

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Users in the same cell have different throughput; and it s traced to differences in core handling;Possibly some users are being routed via a different slice or APN with a capped bandwidth in the core network. A provisioning inconsistency might have placed a subset of users in a restricted QoS category; causing lower throughput for them irrespective of cell conditions
output: Audit the provisioning of the users experiencing lower throughput. Check their subscription profile and slice/APN assignment. If they re incorrectly assigned to a restricted profile or slice; update their subscription to match the intended service level. Also verify PCF rules to ensure no unintended throttling is applied. After re-provisioning; monitor those users (or test with one of their SIMs) to see if throughput now aligns with others in the same cell under similar conditions

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G users observe that browsing and apps work; but initial connection setup (DNS lookups) are slow;The DNS server provided to 5G users might be responding slowly. It could be overloaded; or the UPF is forwarding DNS queries to a distant server. Alternatively; there might be a delay in the DNS queries passing through the core network
output: Check what DNS server IP is assigned to the UEs (via DHCP or NAS). Test the response time of that DNS. If high latency; consider using a more local DNS resolver or deploying a caching DNS in the core or at the UPF. Also ensure multiple DNS servers are configured for redundancy. Implement the changes by updating the DHCP options or UDM profile for UEs; then test again by resolving a common hostname from a UE to confirm quicker DNS response times

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: After a core network software upgrade; some UEs did not reconnect automatically until hours later or after a reboot;Stale context issue: The upgrade might have reset or lost the context of those UEs without notifying them; leaving them in a limbo state. The core might think they re still connected (so it doesn t page them) while the UE thinks it s detached (or vice versa). This mismatch prevents immediate reconnection
output: On noticing the issue; perform a forced detach for the affected UEs from the core side (purge their old sessions in AMF/SMF) so that they are free to reconnect. Alternatively; instruct those users to toggle airplane mode or reboot to trigger a fresh registration. For future upgrades; use a make-before-break strategy or send detach messages to UEs before shutting down to avoid this scenario. Monitor the network post-upgrade to ensure all UEs reconnect properly and no one is left stranded

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G standalone UEs are unable to perform fallback to 4G for voice calls; resulting in call failure (and maybe data interruption);EPS Fallback or RAT fallback for voice (from 5G to 4G) is not configured correctly in the core or not supported by the UE. The UE attempts to place a voice call; the network should move it to LTE (since maybe VoNR is not available); but that procedure fails; dropping the call and potentially the data session
output: Verify that EPS Fallback is configured in the 5G core (AMF) and that the UE s subscription allows for it. Ensure the 5G cells are broadcasting the appropriate indicators for voice fallback. If the UE doesn't support VoNR; the network should trigger a handover to LTE for the call. Configure the necessary policies and test with an affected UE by initiating a voice call. The expected outcome is the UE switches to LTE and the call succeeds. Also confirm data continuity if possible during that switch

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: vRAN: Virtualized DU process stalls due to hypervisor CPU scheduling issues;The virtualized baseband (vDU/vCU) is contending for CPU resources on the cloud host. The hypervisor may not be scheduling the real-time RAN tasks optimally; causing missed processing deadlines (e.g.; scheduling delays) which translate to latency and jitter for users
output: Check the resource allocation for the RAN VNFs on the hypervisor. Ensure that the vDU is configured with real-time CPU scheduling or isolated cores. If CPU contention is observed; migrate the vDU to a host with more available resources or adjust the hypervisor settings (e.g.; CPU pinning; hugepages). Monitor the latency KPI on that cell after changes to ensure the virtualization layer is no longer impacting real-time performance

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A 5G core network function in a container keeps restarting; causing brief service interruptions;The containerized network function (e.g.; AMF or SMF) might be exceeding resource limits or encountering an exception. For instance; it could be running out of memory due to a leak; and the Kubernetes orchestration restarts the pod each time; leading to temporary service loss for attached UEs
output: Inspect the logs and events for the restarting container to identify the cause (memory OOM kill; crash loop; etc.). Increase the resource limits if it s resource starvation; or apply a software patch if it s a bug causing crashes. Optionally; add more instances for load sharing. Once adjustments are made; observe the stability of that network function (no more restarts) and ensure UEs remain attached without interruption

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: After an orchestrator update; some 5G cells went down or became unreachable;An automated configuration pushed by the orchestration system (SDN/NFV orchestrator) contained errors. Possibly wrong IP addresses or VLAN settings were applied to the gNodeB or core interfaces; causing loss of connectivity between RAN and core
output: Roll back the recent changes applied by the orchestrator to restore the last known good configuration. Manually correct any obvious errors in the config (such as reassigning the correct IPs or interface settings) and re-establish connectivity to the gNodeBs. Then; review and test the orchestrator configuration in a staging environment to fix the error before attempting the update again. Verify that all affected cells reconnect to the core and resume normal operation after the fix

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Timing synchronization issues in a virtualized environment leading to TDD slot misalignment;In a cloud RAN setup; the PTP (Precision Time Protocol) timing distribution to the vDU was not stable. The virtual environment introduced jitter in time sync; causing the gNodeB s internal clock to drift and TDD frame alignment issues; which can degrade throughput or violate regulations
output: Check the PTP timing logs on the virtualized RAN components. Ensure the cloud infrastructure provides hardware-assisted timestamping (SyncE or GPS) to the RAN VNFs. If the current host cannot maintain sync; migrate the RAN VNFs to a host with a stable timing source or attach a GPS receiver. After improving sync (e.g.; stabilizing PTP with proper configuration or hardware assist); monitor that the TDD alignment alarm clears and that throughput/latency metrics improve to normal levels

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Integration of a new O-RAN radio unit caused instability and errors on a 5G cell;An interoperability mismatch between the third-party O-RAN RU (Radio Unit) and the DU. Differences in software versions or misaligned configuration (like the eCPRI protocols) can lead to communication errors; resulting in retransmissions or even the cell going down
output: Capture logs on the DU for the fronthaul interface to the RU; looking for protocol errors. Work with the RU vendor to ensure both sides are using compatible O-RAN fronthaul profiles and software releases. Update the DU/RU firmware if needed to a harmonized version. Adjust configuration parameters (like timing advance or compression settings) per vendor recommendations. Once updated; observe the cell s performance and ensure it remains stable with the new RU in operation

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Deployment of a new network slice caused existing slice users to see performance issues;The network slice orchestration allocated network resources in a way that starved an existing slice. Possibly an error in slice resource partitioning (CPU; bandwidth) caused overall resource exhaustion or contention affecting the other slice s throughput
output: Review the slicing configuration on both the core and RAN. Check how resources (like PRBs or QoS scheduling weights; as well as core throughput) are partitioned. If the new slice was given too high a share or not properly isolated; re-balance the allocation to ensure no slice monopolizes resources. Implement proper isolation (e.g.; separate QoS queues) for each slice. After adjustments; monitor the performance indicators of both the new and existing slices to confirm that each is getting its intended share without impacting the other

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Auto-scaling function in the 5G core scaled down network functions; leading to capacity issues;An automated scaling policy misinterpreted a temporary low usage as a trigger to scale in (remove) core network instances; such as shutting down a UPF or AMF instance. When traffic picked up again; there was insufficient capacity; causing congestion and slow responses
output: Examine the auto-scaling logs and rules to determine why the scale-in was triggered. Adjust the thresholds or add a minimum instance floor to prevent scaling in below safe capacity. Immediately redeploy additional instances of the scaled-down network function to restore capacity. In the future; test the scaling policy under various traffic patterns to ensure it only scales in/out at appropriate times. Verify that after adding back resources; the core handles peak traffic without issues and no further unintended scale-in events occur

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Secure communication failure between network elements after a certificate expired;A digital certificate used for secure signaling (for example; TLS on the NG-C interface or IPsec between RAN and core) expired. As a result; gNodeBs could not establish secure connections to the core; or core NFs refused communication; causing service disruption
output: Identify which certificate has expired by checking logs on the affected interfaces (look for TLS handshake failures or certificate errors). Obtain or generate an updated certificate from the certificate authority. Install the new certificate on all relevant network elements (gNodeBs; core nodes) and ensure time synchronization is correct to avoid validity issues. Once updated; verify that secure connections (NG-C; Xn; etc.) can be established normally and that the network elements trust the new certificate

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A mass configuration update introduced a network-wide performance regression;A recent bulk parameter change (for instance; enabling a new feature or altering a common setting) had an unintended side effect that negatively impacted throughput or latency across many cells. This could be due to a software bug triggered by the new setting or simply a suboptimal parameter value
output: Using the change management logs; pinpoint the parameter that was globally modified. Roll back that change on a few test cells to see if performance returns to normal. If yes; perform a controlled rollback network-wide to restore previous settings. If the feature is desired; engage with the vendor to understand the issue and possibly get a fix or a recommended configuration. After rollback; monitor network KPIs closely to confirm that the regression is resolved

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Throughput on a 5G gNodeB is capped due to a software license limitation;The baseband unit or core component has a license-imposed limit (for example; maximum throughput or maximum number of users); and the network has hit that cap. Additional traffic is being dropped or queued; resulting in an artificial ceiling on performance
output: Check the licensing status and performance counters on the suspected network element (gNodeB or UPF). If a license limit is being reached (e.g.; 10 Gbps throughput license cap); procure and apply a license upgrade from the vendor to increase the limit. Alternatively; redistribute load to other elements if possible. After applying the new license; monitor the element to ensure it can now handle increased throughput and verify that users in the area experience higher data rates

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Signaling storm from misbehaving device causes one cell s control-plane to overload;A malicious or malfunctioning device is repeatedly attempting to access the network; causing a signaling storm. For example; a rogue UE might be continuously sending random access requests or attach attempts; overloading the cell s RACH and signaling capacity
output: Use the network s UE logging and intrusion detection systems to identify the source (IMSI or temporary ID) of the excessive attempts. Once identified; block or quarantine that device at the network level (e.g.; in the core or via RAN access control lists). Implement rate limiting on RACH or attach attempts to protect the cell. After mitigating; observe the cell s signaling load returning to normal and verify legitimate users can connect without issues

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G users experience very slow internet because the network s data path is being saturated by junk traffic;A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack is targeting the mobile network s data gateway (UPF) or the internet uplink. The attacker is generating a flood of data (possibly to many UE IP addresses or to the network s public IP) causing congestion that leaves little capacity for normal user traffic
output: Activate DDoS mitigation measures at the network perimeter and UPF. This can include traffic filtering or rate-limiting for suspicious flows (e.g.; drop obviously malicious packets; enable anomaly detection on the UPF). Coordinate with upstream providers if needed to block attack traffic. Once filters are in place; monitor the throughput and ensure that legitimate user traffic speeds improve back to normal levels

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Some users report their phones show a 5G signal but no service; and the network logs show connections to an unknown cell ID;A rogue base station (fake 5G cell) is broadcasting in the area. This illegitimate cell could be luring devices to camp on it (perhaps as an IMSI catcher); which then results in no real service and prevents them from using the actual network. It might also be causing interference on the legitimate network s frequency
output: Perform a spectrum and cell analysis in the reported area using field test equipment to identify unauthorized 5G broadcasts. Once the rogue cell is identified (different cell ID or unauthorized frequency); work with authorities to shut it down. Strengthen network authentication (e.g.; require UE authentication of network where possible) to prevent rogue cell influence. After removal; ensure affected UEs reconnect to the legitimate network and that service is restored

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Multiple 5G sites simultaneously raised sync alarms and saw performance drop due to timing issues;A GPS jamming or interference incident. If many base stations rely on GPS for timing; a strong GPS interference (jammer) in the area can disrupt their sync; leading to TDD frame misalignment and degraded service or even shutdown (if they go into holdover mode)
output: Investigate the geographic pattern of the sync loss. Use spectrum analyzers tuned to GPS frequency to detect jamming signals. Once identified; neutralize the source of interference (via law enforcement if malicious). Meanwhile; switch affected sites to an alternative timing source if available (such as PTP from the network). After restoring GPS; confirm that the sites regain lock and that their performance (e.g.; latency and drop rates) returns to normal

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Core network is seeing a flood of connection setup requests on the AMF; far above normal levels; causing genuine user requests to time out;A denial-of-service attack or network misconfiguration is flooding the AMF with signaling (e.g.; repeated NAS registration attempts). This could be an attacker sending fake registration messages or a misbehaving eNodeB/gNodeB continuously re-initiating connections
output: Examine AMF logs to differentiate legitimate from illegitimate signaling. Deploy security rules to drop or rate-limit suspicious sources (for instance; if coming from an unexpected IP or malformed messages). Ensure that only known gNodeB addresses can send signaling to the AMF (use firewall whitelisting). The AMF might also need a capacity increase or patch if the attack exploited a vulnerability. After mitigation; verify that the signaling load is back to normal and that real user attach success rates are restored

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Large number of 5G attach failures due to authentication rejections in a short time span;A security issue such as an IMSI phishing or credential replay attack. An attacker might be trying to use guessed or stolen subscriber identities to access the network; resulting in many authentication failures. This can strain the authentication servers and cause delays even for legitimate users
output: Inspect the AUSF/UDM logs to see patterns in the failures (same IMSI ranges; same location; etc.). Implement stricter monitoring and possibly temporary bans for IMSIs with repeated failures. If it appears to be an attack; enable two-factor or additional authentication checks for suspicious attempts and alert the security team. Ensure the HSS/UDM is not itself overloaded by the attempts by offloading or rate-limiting auth requests. Once handled; confirm that legitimate subscribers can authenticate quickly and that the burst of failures subsides

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: After a network maintenance window; a key security setting was changed; causing many 5G connections to drop;Human error or misconfiguration: an important parameter like encryption algorithm or integrity protection setting was inadvertently altered (for example; disabling an algorithm that many UEs use); leading to security mismatches that forced UEs off the network
output: Review the recent configuration changes made during maintenance; focusing on security-related settings. Identify the changed parameter (e.g.; allowed cipher suites). Immediately revert it to the previous setting to restore compatibility. If the change was intended; roll it out gradually with proper device compatibility checks. After rollback; monitor UE reconnections and stability; and implement safeguards in change procedures to catch such errors in the future

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A targeted attack or malware on devices is generating a surge of uplink traffic on one slice; saturating it;A targeted attack or malware on devices may be causing an abnormal surge of traffic; such as a botnet of 5G-connected devices all uploading data or hitting specific servers. This flood on a particular slice (for instance; a slice used by IoT devices) overwhelms that slice s resources; impacting those services
output: Identify the traffic pattern (common destination or protocol) and the devices or slice involved. Use network analytics to pinpoint if a particular service or set of IPs is being targeted. Implement rate limiting or blocking for the malicious traffic profile at the UPF or firewall. In parallel; issue alerts to IoT device owners or update device firmware if they were hijacked. After mitigation; verify that slice utilization returns to normal and that legitimate traffic on that slice is no longer affected by the surge

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Some 5G cells suddenly went offline after a security certificate update was pushed network-wide;If the gNodeBs and core use certificates for mutual authentication (e.g.; O-RAN or certain vendor deployments); a faulty certificate update (wrong format or a missed root certificate in some nodes) can cause the gNodeBs to reject the core s connection or vice versa. Essentially; the security handshake fails; and the cells take themselves offline thinking the core is untrusted (or are refused by the core)
output: Roll back the certificate update on either the gNodeB side or core side to the last working certificate. As a temporary measure; if possible; disable strict certificate validation to get sites back up (not ideal for security; but for quick service restoration). Then carefully re-introduce the certificate update: ensure all network elements have the complete certificate chain and correct time synchronization (for validity). Test on a small subset of nodes before wide deployment. Once fixed; confirm that all gNodeBs reconnect to the core without authentication errors

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Unauthorized access to the network management system allowed an intruder to alter a QoS setting; degrading service until discovered;A security breach in the OAM (Operations and Management) domain: someone gained access to the configuration system and changed QoS parameters (for example; lowering the priority of certain user traffic or slices). This act; whether malicious or accidental; caused network performance issues since traffic was no longer prioritized correctly
output: Immediately audit and revert the unexpected configuration changes (restore the original QoS profiles from backups). Investigate the security breach: change passwords; revoke unauthorized accounts; and patch any vulnerability used to gain access. Implement stricter access controls and monitoring on the management system (like 2-factor authentication; role-based permissions; and audit logs alerts). After restoring correct QoS settings; observe network performance to ensure it returns to normal; and keep an eye on management actions for any further anomalies

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Leaving a 5G home small cell causes a momentary data stall;The home 5G small cell (femtocell) is not integrated for seamless mobility. It might not be configured to allow X2/Xn handover to the outdoor macro cell; meaning when a user leaves its coverage; the session can t transfer and must be re-established on macro. This results in a momentary loss of connectivity
output: Verify if the femtocell is set up for handover. If it s a closed access node; it might only release UEs to idle. Enabling handover to macro (if supported by the equipment) would fix this; this involves setting neighbor relations between the femto and macro and ensuring security for handover. If not supported; mitigate by expanding the femto coverage a bit or educating the user that a brief drop may occur. In a network-managed small cell environment; consider software that supports make-before-break (dual connection) when leaving femto coverage. After any configuration changes; test by walking out of the femto coverage during an active session to see if it now remains uninterrupted on macro 5G or LTE

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 5G connectivity on a high-speed train is erratic; with frequent drops or reverts to 4G;High mobility challenge: standard 5G cell handover settings might not cope with very high speeds (~300 km/h). The train crosses cell areas too quickly; and if those cells are not specifically configured (or if using mid/high bands with small footprint); handovers can t complete in time. Additionally; the doppler shift and rapid signal changes at high speed can degrade link quality
output: Implement a high-speed mobility profile along the train route. Use lower-frequency bands (e.g.; sub-1GHz or mid-band with wide spacing) for coverage along rail lines. Configure extended handover regions (perhaps use conditional handover or early preparation of the next cell). Increase handover hysteresis to avoid ping-pong at high speed. Possibly deploy 5G relay devices on the train or special rail-focused antennas along the track. After changes; test the route by measuring continuity of 5G coverage and see if session drop count is reduced at high speeds

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: During big events (e.g.; stadium concerts); 5G speeds plummet and latency rises despite the network being 5G;Extreme cell congestion: even 5G has finite capacity; and a stadium full of users can generate more demand than the deployed infrastructure can handle. If not enough small cells or if insufficient spectrum is allocated; the cell will hit its throughput ceiling and users compete for resources; resulting in each getting only a small share (and the scheduling delays cause latency)
output: Prepare event venues with appropriate capacity. This includes deploying additional 5G small cells (and possibly using mmWave spectrum for localized high capacity) and ensuring the backhaul is scaled up. Use features like load balancing to spread users across cells/sectors (including offload some to LTE or Wi-Fi if available). During events; temporary Cells on Wheels (COWs) can help. Also; implement robust admission control to manage latency (maybe limiting video quality or heavy use temporarily). Monitor network performance in real-time during the event and afterward analyze if further upgrades are needed for future events

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: After a software upgrade; some 5G gNodeBs had trouble communicating with the core until they were rebooted;Version mismatch or stale state: The gNodeBs got new software that perhaps was out-of-sync with core network versions; leading to NG interface message failures. Alternatively; the upgrade left some stale state (like security associations) that a simple reboot cleared. During this period; the cells were not fully attached to the core; affecting user service
output: Immediately reboot or reset the affected gNodeBs to restore connectivity (which appears to have resolved the issue). For a long-term fix; coordinate software versions by either upgrading the core side to match or rolling back gNodeB software if it s incompatible. Work with the vendor to identify the protocol discrepancy and patch it. In future upgrades; perform interoperability testing in a lab with the core version beforehand. Verify post-reboot that all gNodeBs successfully establish NGAP with the core and that UEs can attach normally

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Downlink throughput suddenly dropped due to an increase in radio retransmissions (HARQ) on a cell after a configuration change;A new link adaptation parameter or transmission mode was configured (for example; enabling a new MIMO layer or changing the target error rate) and it wasn t optimal. The cell started choosing too high a modulation/coding for the conditions; causing many transport blocks to error out and require HARQ retransmission. The added retransmissions filled the subframes; effectively reducing net throughput
output: Roll back the recent radio parameter change that affected link adaptation or MIMO. Observe if HARQ failure rate returns to normal. If the feature is beneficial when tuned right; test different configurations in a controlled manner or on a single cell. Adjust the target BLER or the SNR thresholds for switching modulation. The aim is to find a balance where HARQ retransmissions are minimal. After adjustments; monitor the cell s BLER and throughput to confirm that the retransmission rate is low and the throughput is improved

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A new AR/VR edge computing app stopped working because the local MEC server went offline; and traffic wasn t rerouted to the cloud;The MEC (Multi-access Edge Computing) setup for that application had no high availability or fallback. When the local server failed; the network still tried to send traffic to it (via local breakout at the UPF); resulting in a blackhole. Because policies were set to prefer local breakout; the traffic never reached the central server as a backup
output: Detect MEC application/server failures via health checks. Update the routing policy so that if the local edge server is unreachable; traffic automatically falls back to a central cloud server. This might involve configuring the UPF to redirect to core data network upon MEC failure or having the application servers coordinate. In this instance; manually redirect traffic to the central site as a quick fix; then restore the MEC server. For long term; build redundancy for MEC and test that UEs can still use the app even if one edge node goes down; albeit with slightly higher latency

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: The network s automated alarm floods occasionally cause control-plane hiccups;When a large number of alarms or events trigger at once (for example; during a storm many sites report issues); the OAM system can flood the control network with notifications. In some architectures; this shares bandwidth or CPU with signaling; so a storm of OAM messages can ever-so-slightly delay actual user signaling; causing small hiccups or slower handovers
output: Segregate the OAM traffic from the signaling as much as possible (separate VLANs/QoS classes). Tune the alarm reporting rate or batching so that even in a mass outage scenario; the core focus remains on serving users. In this case; while the hiccups were minor; it's a hint to review network management traffic patterns. Implementing rate limits for non-essential messaging during crises can help. After adjustments; simulate a burst of alarms (if feasible) to ensure user-plane and control-plane traffic remain stable and unaffected by the management load

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Upon decommissioning some legacy 4G cells; 5G performance in that area degraded instead of improving as expected;Those 4G cells were actually anchoring NSA connections and carrying non-standalone control-plane traffic. Removing them left a gap where remaining 5G cells had no LTE anchor for NSA; forcing devices either to connect to farther LTE anchors (with worse performance) or drop to standalone 5G which the network might not fully support in that area. It may also be that the 4G removal changed the RF environment (less interference noise for LTE which was helping?) but that s unlikely; the main issue is NSA dependency
output: Ensure when phasing out LTE in an area that either 5G SA is fully available and devices are using it; or maintain some LTE anchor coverage for NSA devices. In this scenario; consider quickly filling the gap by enabling SA 5G on those cells or deploying a low-band 5G carrier to handle coverage. Also update device configuration via NAS signaling to prefer SA if NSA anchor is gone. After adjustments; test UEs in that area to see if they can attach and maintain performance on 5G (whether via SA mode or a more distant but still sufficient LTE anchor)

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Some 5G IoT devices (like security cameras) show connectivity but their data isn t reaching the server due to a mis-provisioned APN;The APN these IoT devices use might be incorrectly set up in the core routing. They attach and get IPs; but their traffic is either not leaving the mobile network or is being dropped by a firewall because the APN was supposed to be restricted/tunneled. Possibly the APN was meant to route to a private enterprise network but lacks the proper tunnel or connection; resulting in no path to the public internet or the intended server
output: Inspect the APN (DNN) configuration for the IoT devices in the SMF/UPF. Determine where the traffic is intended to go (enterprise VPN; internet; etc.). If it s supposed to go to a corporate network; set up the required GRE/IPSec tunnel or APN routing to that network. If it should go to internet; ensure it s not mistakenly classified as a closed/private APN. Also verify any firewall rules associated with that APN. After fixing the provisioning and network route; test connectivity from an IoT device  it should be able to send data to its server and receive responses normally

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Continuous ping tests indicate a periodic spike in latency exactly every 10 minutes on 5G; on an otherwise idle connection;This periodicity suggests a scheduled network routine  perhaps a paging cycle or system info broadcast; or even a background self-optimization task. Every 10 minutes; resources might be briefly diverted (e.g.; the cell might broadcast SIB or measure neighboring cells); causing a momentary increase in latency for ongoing data. Another possibility is a periodic context refresh in core (like security key update interval) that momentarily impacts the flow
output: Correlate the timing with network logs. Check if; for instance; system information is being updated on that schedule (maybe overly frequent). If a periodic measurement gap is scheduled too often; consider reducing its frequency if not needed. Also see if NAS security rekeying is set to 10 minutes; if so; perhaps extend it to reduce frequency of interruption. After any changes; run the ping test again to see if the 10-minute spike has been smoothed out or significantly reduced. The goal is to eliminate unnecessary periodic tasks that disrupt user plane if possible

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A bug in the network slicing orchestration caused some users to be assigned to the wrong slice; limiting their connectivity;The provisioning system mistakenly tagged certain subscribers or application flows with an incorrect slice ID (S-NSSAI). As a result; they were routed into a slice that might not have access to the internet or the services they need (for example; a slice meant for a private enterprise). This misrouting can restrict or isolate their traffic; giving the impression of network issues
output: Audit the subscriber profiles and the slice assignment logic in the NSSF/UDM. Identify the mis-tagged users (maybe by tracking complaints or unusual slice usage logs). Correct their slice identifiers in the provisioning database and trigger an update (or have them reconnect). Also fix the orchestration rule that made the mistake; to prevent new misassignments. After correction; monitor those users  connectivity  they should now be on the proper public slice and have normal access. Additionally; implement a sanity check in the slice controller to catch anomalies like consumer IMSIs showing up in enterprise slices

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Interference from 5G to satellite services was reported in C-Band; causing a regulatory concern and forced power reduction;In some regions; mid-band 5G (around 3.5 GHz) can potentially interfere with satellite downlink (like C-band satellite TV). If tower emissions leaked into the satellite band or overloaded nearby satellite receivers; complaints could arise. The network may have had to reduce power on certain frequencies to mitigate this; which in turn reduces 5G coverage/throughput in those cells
output: Conduct joint testing with the satellite service representatives. Ensure all 5G transmitters are within their spectral masks and not exceeding power toward horizon (satellite dish elevation). If interference persists; install filters on the satellite receivers or create a small guard band at the band edge. Temporarily; the network might lower power on the affected frequencies as done. After mitigation (filters on satellite or tuning 5G); gradually bring 5G power back up if allowed and observe if any interference reports recur. Maintain compliance with any regulatory mandates in that spectrum to avoid service restrictions

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: A miscommunication between two overlapping 5G networks (multi-operator scenario) caused user devices to frequently switch networks or lose service;In some areas; two operators might share infrastructure or have overlapping coverage. If a device is allowed (e.g.; via eSIM or roaming agreement) to access both; it might oscillate if not properly controlled. Or possibly one network s signals were mistakenly identified as the other s due to identical IDs (MCC/MNC confusion in a shared RAN scenario). This resulted in devices trying to authenticate on the 'wrong' core and failing
output: Clarify and correct the network broadcasting IDs and access agreements in that area. If this is a MOCN (Multi-Operator Core Network) sharing scenario; ensure each cell broadcasts the correct PLMN IDs and that each device knows which one to prefer. If devices were bouncing due to roaming settings; update their SIM provisioning to favor the home network. Also; coordinate with the other operator to adjust signal power balance if one network s coverage bleeds too much into the other s territory. After fixes; test with devices to confirm they stick to the intended network and don t see unexpected service drops or switches

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: fault UPF is not responding to initial PFCP association #1. SMF logs show repeated PFCP Association Request timeouts with no response from the UPF (context ID 1)
output: Ensure the UPF process is running and that the SMF can reach the UPF on the N4 interface. Verify the PFCP port and matching IPs in configuration. Restart UPF if needed. [case 1]

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: PFCP version mismatch preventing session establishment #2. SMF error logs indicate PFCP Session Establishment messages are rejected with cause protocol version not supported (context ID 2)
output: Update UPF to a compatible version or configure to match SMF's PFCP version. Confirm supported release on both sides. [case 2]

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF not sending PFCP heartbeat responses #3. SMF triggers heartbeat requests but receives no acknowledgments from UPF (context ID 3)

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM cannot retrieve subscriber data from UDR. During user registration UDM returned empty subscriber information to AMF

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM fails to fetch subscription profile. At random intervals UDM fetch operations time out while querying UDR for subscriber data
output: Possible causes may include intermittent network delays or UDR response latency; Steps: check network latency and packet loss; monitor UDR performance; consider optimizing database queries or scaling resources

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM responding with error code 404 for subscriber query. AMF reports that UDM returned error code 404 when retrieving data for a known subscriber
output: Possible causes may include subscriber profile missing or incorrect identifier mapping; Steps: verify the subscriber SUPI or identifier used; ensure subscriber data is provisioned in UDR; correct any identifier mapping issues

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM returning HTTP 500 internal error on data request. After a configuration change SMF API calls to UDM started getting HTTP 500 errors
output: Possible causes are misconfiguration in UDM or a software bug triggered by the new config; Steps: review recent configuration changes; check UDM logs for exceptions; roll back the change or apply a patch if a bug is identified

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM not discoverable by other network functions. New AMF instances are unable to find the UDM service during registration attempts
output: Possible causes may include UDM not registered with NRF or incorrect NRF address configuration; Steps: verify UDM is registered and visible in NRF; check UDM NRF registration configuration; restart UDM if necessary to re-register

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM duplicate registration causing conflicts. NRF shows two entries for UDM with slight differences after an upgrade
output: Possible causes include an upgrade misconfiguration leading to multiple UDM identities in NRF; Steps: deregister the duplicate UDM entry from NRF; ensure only one active UDM instance is registered; update configuration to prevent future duplication

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM session registration in NRF expired. Periodic heartbeats from UDM to NRF were missed causing NRF to mark UDM as inactive
output: Possible causes may include UDM service hang or network issues dropping heartbeat messages; Steps: ensure UDM is running and healthy; check connectivity to NRF; restart UDM service to re-register if needed

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM high CPU usage causing slow responses. Monitoring alerts show UDM CPU at 95% during peak load and response times spiking
output: Possible causes include high subscriber query volume or inefficient processing; Steps: analyze traffic load; optimize UDM configuration or caching; scale out with additional UDM instances or increase CPU resources

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM memory leak suspected after prolonged uptime. UDM service memory grows continuously and requires a restart every few days to avoid crash
output: Possible causes likely a software bug causing memory not to be freed; Steps: collect memory usage data and logs for analysis; apply vendor patch or upgrade to a fixed version; schedule periodic restarts as a temporary workaround

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM response latency due to UDR slowness. Trace shows UDM taking 3 seconds to respond to data queries during high load
output: Possible causes are UDR database slow queries or contention affecting UDM responses; Steps: examine UDR query performance; optimize database indices or queries; consider increasing UDR capacity to reduce latency

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM configuration mismatch with UDR. After a database schema update UDM started throwing errors retrieving certain fields
output: Possible causes include UDM expecting a different data schema or field names; Steps: verify UDM is updated to match UDR schema changes; update UDM configuration or version as needed; coordinate schema changes between UDM and UDR

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM TLS handshake failure with UDR. UDM logs show TLS handshake errors when connecting to UDR after a certificate update
output: Possible causes include certificate trust issues or protocol mismatch; Steps: verify that UDM trusts the new UDR certificate; check TLS version and cipher compatibility; update trust store or certificate configuration; retry connection

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM using wrong credentials for UDR database. UDM attempts to access UDR result in authentication failures after a password rotation
output: Possible cause is that UDM config was not updated with the new UDR credentials; Steps: update UDM configuration with the correct database credentials; restart UDM to apply changes; ensure future password changes are synchronized across components

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Inconsistent subscriber data between UDM and UDR. Subscriber profile data retrieved by UDM does not match the latest updates made in UDR
output: Possible causes include caching issues or replication delay in the UDR cluster; Steps: clear or refresh UDM cache if applicable; verify UDR cluster replication is up to date; perform a manual data sync or consistency check for the affected subscriber

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM fails to update subscriber location information. After handover to a new cell the UDM did not update the subscriber‚Äôs serving AMF entry
output: Possible causes are an internal UDM update error or subscription data conflict; Steps: check UDM logs for update errors; ensure no duplicate subscriber entry exists; if reproducible escalate for a software fix to UDM update logic

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM returns partial data for subscriber profile. UDM response to SMF is missing optional subscriber settings such as APN configurations
output: Possible causes may be misconfigured data in UDR or UDM filtering out unrecognized fields; Steps: verify subscriber profile completeness in UDR; update any missing fields; ensure UDM version supports all required data fields; apply updates if necessary

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SIDF failure in UDM for identifier de-concealment. UDM logs show an error de-concealing the SUCI for certain new SIM cards
output: Possible causes include an unsupported or misconfigured algorithm in the Subscription Identifier De-concealing Function; Steps: verify that UDM supports the SUCI encryption scheme used; update UDM algorithm settings or software version to add support; coordinate with the SIM vendor if required

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM ARPF generated invalid authentication vectors. During authentication some UEs experienced immediate failure with mismatched authentication response values
output: Possible causes include a fault in the Authentication credential Repository and Processing Function within UDM; Steps: check if ARPF configuration (such as sequence numbers or keys) is correct; resynchronize authentication data for affected UEs; apply vendor patch if the issue is a known bug in auth vector generation

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM unexpected reboot observed. The UDM node restarted automatically during a heavy load test with no manual intervention
output: Possible causes might be a crash due to an unhandled exception or a hardware watchdog trigger; Steps: review UDM core dumps or logs around the time of reboot; check for any known software bugs; consider a hardware health check; implement redundancy to handle future unexpected reboots

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM error during subscriber deregistration. When a UE disconnected the AMF logged an error from UDM while removing the subscriber registration
output: Possible causes include a UDM internal error or race condition during deregistration; Steps: check if UDM received the deregistration notice properly; inspect UDM logs for exceptions; consider a software update if a deregistration bug is known

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM failed to update subscriber data in UDR. A profile change (e.g. new service activation) did not reflect in UDR as UDM returned an update failure
output: Possible causes may be a database constraint violation or UDR connection glitch during the update; Steps: verify data integrity and constraints in UDR; retry the update operation; if issue persists check UDM logs for error details and escalate to database admin

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM delivered outdated subscriber profile. After a SIM swap the network still received old subscriber details from UDM for several minutes
output: Possible causes include caching in UDM or delayed synchronization with UDR; Steps: confirm if UDM caching is enabled and adjust cache TTL if necessary; ensure UDR replication or sync has completed; clear any stale data entries manually if needed

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM returned incorrect subscriber information. During testing one UE received profile data belonging to a different subscriber
output: Possible causes might be a rare indexing or cache bug causing an ID mismatch; Steps: immediately check UDM logs and trace requests to identify how the mix-up occurred; verify UDR query keys and indexes; apply an urgent software fix or patch to prevent data mismatches

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM using outdated data after restoration. Following a UDR backup restore UDM was still serving data from an older snapshot
output: Possible causes are UDM not refreshing its data or pointing to an old data source; Steps: ensure UDM is pointed to the current UDR database; flush any in-memory cache UDM may hold; if needed restart UDM to force reloading of current data

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM denied data request due to authorization policy. A network function was blocked from retrieving user data because UDM enforced an unknown policy rule
output: Possible causes include misconfigured authorization policies or a wrong NF identity presented; Steps: verify the requesting NF has proper permissions in UDM; review UDM policy configurations; adjust or disable the conflicting policy rule as appropriate

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Stale user registration not cleared in UDM. UDM still showed a user as registered to an old AMF long after the user detached and moved
output: Possible causes include UDM not receiving the detach notification or failure to update its record; Steps: manually deregister the stale entry; check the signaling path for detach messages; fix any issues in deregistration handling in UDM software

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM running at capacity limits. After adding a large batch of new subscribers UDM performance degraded significantly
output: Possible causes are hitting memory or processing limits with the increased data load; Steps: check UDM capacity and memory usage; scale the UDM vertically (add memory/CPU) or horizontally (additional instances); optimize data handling or purge obsolete data if possible

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM error on handling multiple network slices for a user. A subscriber with access to multiple slices caused UDM to throw an error when retrieving slice-specific data
output: Possible causes may be a software limitation or bug in handling multiple slice profiles; Steps: verify if UDM version supports multi-slice profiles; apply updates or patches that address multi-slice handling; in the interim reduce slice assignments or test with separate profiles

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: High latency when UDM processes roaming subscriber data. When roaming users attached UDM took longer than normal to provide subscription data to AMF
output: Possible causes include extra processing for roaming checks or remote database queries; Steps: ensure roaming configuration in UDM is optimized; check if UDM queries external data for roaming and cache or optimize it; monitor if specific roaming scenarios cause the delay

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM configuration error after software upgrade. Post-upgrade UDM failed to start due to an unknown configuration parameter
output: Possible causes include deprecated or renamed config settings in the new version; Steps: review release notes for configuration changes; update the UDM configuration file to remove or correct invalid parameters; once fixed start UDM and monitor for successful startup

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM thread exhaustion under heavy load. At 10k concurrent requests UDM stopped responding and new requests were dropped
output: Possible causes include running out of threads or connections due to high concurrency; Steps: increase thread pool or connection limits for UDM; implement load balancing to spread requests; optimize request handling to reduce per-request resource usage

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM reached maximum allowed subscriber sessions. Beyond a certain number of active users new registration attempts were being refused by UDM
output: Possible causes could be a configured capacity limit or license restriction on UDM; Steps: verify if UDM has a subscriber or session limit setting; if so increase the limit or obtain a higher capacity license; as a workaround distribute load across additional UDM instances

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM failover did not preserve active sessions. During a planned UDM node switch some ongoing subscriber requests failed instead of transferring to the backup node
output: Possible causes include improper failover configuration or state not shared between UDM instances; Steps: review UDM clustering and state sharing settings; test state replication if applicable; improve failover procedures to ensure seamless transition

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM excessive logging causing performance degradation. Debug mode was left enabled on UDM generating huge log volumes and slowing down processing
output: Possible cause is verbose logging consuming CPU and I-O resources; Steps: disable or reduce logging level on UDM in production; archive or rotate large logs to free I-O; ensure debug logging is only enabled when needed

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM crashed when receiving malformed request. A misbehaving network element sent a malformed message causing UDM to crash on parsing
output: Possible causes include a software bug where UDM did not handle unexpected message formats; Steps: identify the source of malformed messages and correct it; update UDM software with a fix for robust input parsing; consider adding input validation to protect UDM

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM authentication sequence number mismatch. A group of UEs consistently failed authentication until an AKA resynchronization was performed
output: Possible cause is out-of-sync sequence numbers in UDM‚Äôs authentication repository; Steps: perform an authentication resync for affected UEs (AUTS procedure); investigate how the sequence got out of sync; ensure UDM properly updates sequence numbers after each authentication

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM slow due to heavy analytics data queries. During a network analytics operation NWDAF pulled large amounts of subscriber data from UDM causing slowdowns
output: Possible causes are resource-intensive data requests impacting UDM performance; Steps: schedule large data queries during off-peak hours; if possible offload analytics data from UDR directly; upgrade UDM resources or optimize query handling for large requests

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM node network interface failure. One UDM instance became unreachable due to a network interface malfunction causing partial service disruption
output: Possible causes include a hardware NIC failure or misconfigured network settings; Steps: switch traffic to healthy UDM instances; replace or repair the faulty network interface; verify network configuration and consider redundant network paths for UDM nodes

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM upgrade procedure caused unexpected downtime. During what was supposed to be an in-service software upgrade UDM stopped serving requests briefly
output: Possible causes include an upgrade process that required a restart or froze service; Steps: review upgrade procedures to ensure high availability (such as rolling upgrades); if upgrade caused downtime plan for a maintenance window; consider deploying upgrades to standby instances first

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM not accepting HTTP2 connections from peers. After a certificate update other NFs could not establish HTTP2 sessions with UDM and had to retry
output: Possible causes include protocol or TLS configuration mismatch after the certificate change; Steps: verify UDM supports HTTP2 and that ALPN settings are correct; ensure certificates and TLS configuration allow HTTP2; adjust configuration or reinstall the certificate if necessary

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR service unreachable. UDM reported that UDR did not respond to data query requests during a network test
output: Possible causes include the UDR service being down or network connectivity issues; Steps: check if the UDR application is running; verify network connectivity between UDM and UDR; restart the UDR service if it was down and monitor

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR database connection failure. UDR logs show errors connecting to its underlying database after a failover event
output: Possible causes may be the database server not reachable or an incorrect connection string after failover; Steps: check the status of the database server; verify UDR configuration for database connection; update connection parameters or restart services if needed

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR not responding to API calls. During load testing UDR stopped responding to API queries from UDM and PCF intermittently
output: Possible causes include the UDR service hanging or overload leading to dropped requests; Steps: review UDR server CPU and memory during incidents; check for deadlocks or crashes in UDR logs; consider increasing resources or breaking the load into smaller batches

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR high latency on data requests. Multiple timeouts were recorded by UDM when waiting for responses from UDR
output: Possible causes are slow database queries or insufficient processing power on UDR; Steps: analyze database performance for slow queries; add indexes or optimize query logic; scale UDR vertically or horizontally to handle load with lower latency

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR database connection pool exhausted. At peak traffic times UDR started rejecting requests with errors indicating no available DB connections
output: Possible causes include too low a database connection pool limit or a connection leak not releasing connections; Steps: increase the database connection pool size in UDR configuration if appropriate; ensure connections are closed properly after queries; monitor DB usage for connection leaks

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR primary database instance down. UDR switched to a backup database after the primary became unreachable which caused slight data staleness
output: Possible causes could be a crash or network issue with the primary database; Steps: investigate why the primary database went down (check DB server logs); ensure the failover mechanism worked and update any lost data when primary is restored; consider redundancy improvements

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR disk space exhausted. UDR server stopped accepting new subscriber entries because its storage was full
output: Possible causes are logs or data consuming all disk space; Steps: clear unnecessary logs or old data from UDR storage; extend storage capacity or add a new volume; implement monitoring alerts for disk usage to prevent future occurrences

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR out of memory error. During a batch update of subscriber data the UDR service crashed with an out-of-memory condition
output: Possible causes include a memory leak or insufficient memory allocation for handling large data sets; Steps: check for memory leaks in UDR by analyzing logs or heap dumps; increase memory allocation or limit batch sizes; update UDR software if a leak is identified

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR error writing to database. While provisioning new subscribers UDR logged errors indicating it could not write data to the database
output: Possible causes could be database write permission issues or a transaction rollback due to constraint violations; Steps: verify database permissions for UDR; check for any unique constraint or validation errors on the new data; correct the data and retry provisioning

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR data inconsistency between cluster nodes. Different UDR nodes returned different data for the same subscriber ID during a test
output: Possible causes include replication lag or a failure in synchronizing data across UDR cluster nodes; Steps: check replication status and logs between UDR nodes; resynchronize the data manually if needed; fix any issues in the replication mechanism and monitor consistency

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR replication delay observed. Updates to subscriber profiles took several minutes to reflect on a secondary UDR node
output: Possible causes could be high replication traffic or network latency between data centers; Steps: optimize replication settings for faster sync; ensure network links between UDR nodes have sufficient bandwidth; as a workaround direct read requests to the primary node until the delay is resolved

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR failover led to outdated data being served. After a failover to a standby UDR node some subscriber queries returned old data
output: Possible causes include the standby node not having recent updates (lagging behind primary); Steps: improve the data synchronization frequency or mechanism for the standby node; after failover run a data consistency check; update the out-of-date entries from backups or primary

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR returned null for existing subscriber. Occasionally UDM receives an empty result from UDR even though the subscriber exists in the database
output: Possible causes include a query bug or a caching issue returning a miss; Steps: inspect the UDR query and parameters for errors; check if a caching layer is present and possibly returning stale misses; apply a fix or patch if a bug is found in the query logic

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR data corruption detected. Routine data audit found corrupted entries in UDR for a few subscribers (data fields with invalid values)
output: Possible causes might be software bugs writing bad data or storage issues; Steps: identify and isolate corrupted entries; restore correct data from backup if available; run diagnostics on UDR software and storage systems for errors; apply fixes and closely monitor data integrity

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR CPU utilization at maximum. Performance monitoring showed UDR CPU at 100% during busy hours affecting response times
output: Possible causes are insufficient processing power or inefficient queries causing CPU strain; Steps: profile the UDR to find hot spots or expensive operations; optimize code or queries causing high CPU usage; consider upgrading CPU or adding more UDR instances to distribute load

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR query throughput bottleneck. UDM and PCF queries to UDR were throttled because UDR could not handle more than a certain number of queries per second
output: Possible causes include a fixed throughput limit or hardware constraints; Steps: check if UDR software has configurable throughput or thread limits and increase them if needed; scale out UDR horizontally to handle more queries; implement query caching or load distribution to reduce the burden

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDR lacking index causing slow queries. A specific query for subscriber data took over 5 seconds to return results from UDR for large tables
