The recommended action is to update the SMF configuration according to security best practices. For example you can strengthen encryption settings or tighten access controls to eliminate the vulnerability.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF failover event causes partial session loss. The primary SMF went down and the secondary took over. Some sessions were lost in the process. A number of users had to reconnect their data sessions.
output: Likely cause is that not all session state was synced to the standby or the failover procedure had an issue. Check the state synchronization between the primary and backup SMF. Fine-tune the failover configuration based on the findings. Complete state replication will minimize session loss in future failovers.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: small glitch during SMF redundancy switch. A brief hiccup occurred during a planned switchover from the primary to the secondary SMF. A handful of sessions were momentarily interrupted but quickly recovered.
output: This glitch suggests a timing issue in the redundancy procedure. The solution is to adjust the failover process timing or sequence. Testing the redundancy in a controlled manner can help ensure a smoother transition with zero impact next time.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: standby SMF synchronization issue leads to unsynchronized sessions. The standby SMF was out of sync with the active one for a period. A failover was attempted and some session contexts were missing on the standby. This caused those sessions to drop.
output: The cause was that replication of session state between the active and standby SMF was incomplete. Troubleshoot by reviewing synchronization logs and ensuring the mechanism is functioning in real time. Resolve any faults in the replication link or process. Consider forcing periodic full state checks to keep the standby updated.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: cluster failover did not fully preserve sessions during test. A disaster recovery test was conducted to switch over the SMF to a backup site. After failover
output: some users had to re-establish sessions. This indicates not all session data carried over. Likely cause is an issue in the inter-site SMF failover process or data replication latency. Improvement is needed in the failover design. Optimize data replication across sites and verify procedures for transferring control without losing sessions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF active-standby switch triggers unexpected behavior. An automated SMF failover occurred after a heartbeat was missed. The standby took over. Some users experienced unusual session behavior like brief data stalls.
output: The failover mechanism worked but not perfectly smoothly. The cause may be a slight delay or race condition in the takeover. Fine-tune the heartbeat and takeover thresholds. Update the SMF software if there is a known bug causing issues on failover. Additional testing can validate the stability of the failover mechanism.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF session count threshold alarm triggered under load. The number of active sessions approached a high threshold during a busy period. This triggered an alarm. Service continued without an outage.
output: The alarm indicates the system is nearing its capacity limit. There is no immediate failure but it serves as a warning. The recommended action is to consider increasing capacity or adjusting the threshold. Continue to monitor session counts to ensure the SMF can handle projected loads.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF memory usage alert with no service impact. A memory utilization alarm for SMF was raised when usage spiked but it went back down shortly after. Users did not notice any issue.
output: This was likely a false alarm or momentary peak. It had no effect on service. The advice is to verify memory usage patterns and possibly raise the alert threshold if it is set too low. Additionally optimize memory usage if these spikes happen often.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF CPU high utilization alarm auto-cleared. SMF CPU usage briefly exceeded a threshold and triggered an alarm. The utilization dropped before any manual action could be taken and the alarm cleared itself.
output: This incident suggests the threshold might have been set too low or the spike was very temporary. No immediate action is required other than verifying that the CPU usage returned to normal. Adjust the threshold or continue to monitor CPU patterns to ensure this is not a sign of a developing problem.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF response time KPI slightly degraded without user impact. Performance metrics show SMF response time increased slightly above target during a short interval. No user complaints were reported and service remained stable.
output: This KPI deviation could be due to a transient condition. There is no direct impact. It is worth noting and keeping under observation. Fine-tuning performance parameters or investigating any events during that interval might provide insights to maintain optimal response times.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF not sending usage reports to charging system. The post call billing data is not being updated. The charging function shows no usage records coming from the SMF. Sessions are running normally.
output: Likely cause is a fault in the interface between the SMF and the charging system. The SMF might have a misconfiguration or connection issue preventing usage data transfer. Check the charging interface configuration on the SMF and ensure connectivity. Then re-establish the reporting to the billing system.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: billing record generation issue in SMF with no user impact. The billing system reports some missing usage records from SMF. Users are not affected in real time but the missing records could cause incomplete billing for some sessions.
output: The cause is possibly a software bug or timing issue in usage data generation. You should verify the SMF CDR and usage report logs. Ensure the records are queued and sent correctly. A software patch might be needed to fix the record generation bug. There is no immediate service impact.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF system clock offset triggers synchronization warning. Network management raised a time synchronization warning for the SMF node. The SMF clock was a few minutes off from the standard time source. Services ran normally.
output: This likely resulted from an NTP synchronization issue or a misconfigured time server. The fix is to resync the SMF system clock with the network time protocol source. Ensuring consistent time sync will prevent potential issues with time-dependent processes or logs.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: duplicate session context causing errors on user reconnect. A user reconnects quickly after a drop and the SMF logs show an error about an existing session entry. The user then has difficulty reconnecting immediately due to this error.
output: Likely cause is that the previous session was not fully cleared from the SMF. This leads to a conflict. Troubleshoot by examining SMF session release procedures and timers. Adjust the configuration to release or reuse session IDs faster. Apply patches if available to handle rapid reconnect scenarios properly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: misconfigured DNS server address in SMF affecting connectivity. Users obtain an IP address but cannot reach any websites or services. Investigation reveals that the DNS server address provided to UEs via SMF is incorrect.
output: The cause is a configuration error in the DNS settings on the SMF or in the subscriber data. Update the SMF configuration or the subscriber profile with the correct DNS server addresses. New sessions will receive the proper DNS information once the configuration is corrected. This will restore normal connectivity.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: uneven load distribution across SMF instances causing overload. In a multi-SMF deployment one SMF instance is handling far more session requests than others. That instance becomes overloaded while the others are underutilized.
output: Likely cause is an issue with load balancing or SMF selection by the network possibly due to a configuration bias in the AMF or NRF. The solution is to adjust the SMF selection algorithm or registration weights so that traffic is evenly spread. Each SMF will carry an appropriate share of the load after rebalancing.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF internal state inconsistency leads to unpredictable behavior. After a certain event the SMF internal state or database became inconsistent. Some sessions are stuck or behaving oddly. Errors appear when managing those sessions.
output: Possible cause is a software bug causing internal data corruption possibly triggered by an abnormal shutdown or an edge case event. The SMF may need a restart to clear the inconsistent state. Also analyze logs to identify what led to the corruption and apply vendor fixes or configuration changes to prevent recurrence.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF license limit reached causing capacity outage. The SMF has reached the maximum number of sessions allowed by its license. Any new user attempting to establish a session is denied and this effectively halts new connections.
output: This is a capacity issue caused by a license cap. The immediate step is to contact the vendor to extend the license or apply a temporary key if available. Also manage the current sessions and possibly release any inactive sessions. Ensure the license capacity is sufficient for peak demand to avoid such hard cutoffs in the future.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF configured with wrong endpoint for subscriber data service. SMF is failing to retrieve subscriber information because it is querying the wrong address. The network database (UDM) is running but SMF is not reaching it due to the misconfiguration.
output: The cause is a misconfigured endpoint or address for the UDM in the SMF settings. Update the SMF configuration to point to the correct UDM service address and credentials. Verify connectivity and that SMF can successfully query subscriber profiles after the correction.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: 4G to 5G handover to SA core fails at SMF stage. Users on LTE (4G) attempt to hand over to the 5G Standalone core. The data session setup in 5G fails. The handover aborts and the users fall back to 4G.
output: Likely cause is an interworking configuration issue or an incompatible session context transfer to the 5G SMF. The SMF might not accept the incoming session request due to a missing mapping of 4G parameters such as APN to DNN or other profile mismatches. Troubleshoot by checking the N26 interface settings on the SMF. Ensure the 4G context is properly translated for 5G. Adjust the configuration or apply updates to allow a seamless handover.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: recurring error message in SMF logs with no impact. The SMF logs show a specific error message appearing repeatedly. It occurs roughly every hour. There is no corresponding issue in service observed for users.
output: This is likely a benign software bug that triggers an error log without affecting functionality. The recommended step is to report it to the vendor for correction in a future update. It can be monitored in the short term and does not require immediate action since it does not impact users.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF debug mode left enabled causing high log volume. Debug logging remained on for SMF after a troubleshooting session. The system continues to function normally but it is generating an unusually high volume of log data.
output: The cause is simply that a verbose logging setting was not turned off. This can fill up disk space or slightly affect performance if left unchecked. The solution is to disable debug logging and revert to normal logging levels. Housekeeping can be done to clear out excessive log files.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF statistics reporting discrepancy in monitoring tools. Network monitoring tools show static or incorrect session counts for the SMF but the actual sessions on the network are fine.
output: This is likely due to a fault in the SMF statistics reporting functionality or an issue in its interface to the monitoring system. The service itself is unaffected. To fix this you might reset the SMF stats counters or reconnect the monitoring feed. Apply a software patch if available to correct the reporting error so that monitoring reflects accurate information.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF software bug triggers repeated crashes under specific condition. The SMF crashes and restarts whenever a certain rare event occurs. For example a specific message sequence from a UE can trigger this failure. This has happened multiple times and caused intermittent outages.
output: This is due to a severe software bug in the SMF that is reproducibly triggered by that event. The immediate action is to avoid the triggering scenario if possible and work with the vendor for an urgent fix. A patch or update is required to resolve the bug. Increase monitoring and prepare a contingency plan for quick SMF restarts until a fix is available to mitigate the impact.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF certificate expiration causes core communication breakdown. The SMF security certificate expired. As a result other core network functions are refusing connections. No new sessions can be established and some control-plane interactions are failing.
output: The cause is the expiration of the SMF certificate used for secure communication. This issue requires installing a valid certificate on the SMF and updating the trust relationships. Normal secure communication will resume once the certificate is renewed and distributed. Implement proactive certificate management to prevent future expirations from going unnoticed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF node experiences a complete service outage leading to a total loss of 5G data connectivity for all users in the network. All 5G UEs in the network are unable to attach or use data services. The gNB indicates no response from the AMF on the N2 interface. NAS registration attempts from UEs do not receive any reply from the core.
output: The root cause is an AMF software crash causing a full outage. Troubleshooting involves immediate restart of the AMF node and checking core network alarms. Log analysis revealed a memory leak leading to the crash. After applying a software patch to fix the memory leak; the AMF was stabilized and normal data service resumed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF loses connectivity with all gNodeBs due to SCTP link failure resulting in a network wide data service disruption. Every connected gNodeB reports lost association with the AMF. No NGAP messages are observed in the AMF during the outage. UEs cannot complete registration or maintain existing sessions.
output: Root cause was an SCTP connection failure between gNodeBs and the AMF. Network checks found a misconfigured IP route on the AMF that dropped SCTP traffic. The resolution involved correcting the IP routing configuration and re-establishing the SCTP associations. Once fixed; NGAP signaling resumed and data services were restored.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to forward PDU session establishment requests to the SMF preventing UEs from establishing new data sessions. UEs successfully register with the network but cannot establish data sessions. The AMF receives PDU session establishment NAS requests but the SMF does not receive any session create request. AMF logs show repeated NAS requests with no corresponding N11 messaging to the SMF.
output: Root cause is a bug in the AMF software that halted N11 interface messages. The AMF was not sending PDU session create messages to the SMF due to a process error. Troubleshooting included analyzing AMF logs and observing that NAS requests were not followed by N11 interactions. A software fix was applied to the AMF to correct the process handling; and after restarting the AMF node UEs were able to establish data sessions normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF not retrieving subscriber data from UDM leading to failed service authorization for 5G data sessions. Newly attaching UEs are stuck in limited service state. The registration seems to proceed; but when establishing a data session the network fails to authorize the service. AMF logs indicate missing subscription data during the session setup procedure.
output: The AMF could not retrieve subscriber profile information from the UDM due to a connection outage. The root cause was a UDM interface failure. The fix required restoring connectivity to the UDM and ensuring the UDM is responsive. After re-establishing the AMF-UDM link; subscription data was properly retrieved and UEs could complete data session setup.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Authentication failures at the AMF causing all new 5G data sessions to be rejected. All new UEs are failing to register or establish data sessions. The AMF shows multiple authentication rejects. NAS messages indicate that the authentication procedure cannot complete. None of the UEs are obtaining 5G service.
output: The root cause was an AMF configuration error with the AUSF credentials. The AMF was using an incorrect key for authentication causing every authentication attempt to fail. Troubleshooting involved verifying the AUSF connection and credentials in the AMF configuration. After correcting the authentication key and restarting the authentication service on the AMF; UEs were able to authenticate successfully and obtain data connectivity.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF experiences CPU overload resulting in widespread latency and data session setup failures. During a sudden surge of network traffic; the AMF becomes unresponsive. Many UEs experience timeouts during registration and PDU session establishment. The network monitoring shows the AMF CPU at maximum utilization; NAS and NGAP message handling is severely delayed.
output: The root cause was CPU overload on the AMF due to an unexpected signaling storm. To resolve this; non-logging was temporarily disabled to reduce load and additional AMF instances were brought online to share the load. Operators also implemented rate limiting on incoming NAS requests to stabilize the AMF. After these actions; the AMF responsiveness returned to normal and UEs could register and establish data sessions again.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to allocate correct network slice causing UEs to be unable to obtain data service on their intended slice. UEs attempting to connect to a specific network slice cannot get a data session. The registration completes but the PDU session for that slice fails. AMF logs show that no appropriate slice (S-NSSAI) was assigned to the PDU session request. Many UEs are left without data connectivity on that slice.
output: Root cause was a misconfiguration of network slice parameters in the AMF. The slice was not properly configured or mapped to an SMF; so slice-specific session requests were failing. The resolution involved updating the AMF configuration with the correct S-NSSAI mapping to an available SMF. After reconfiguring and syncing the slice information; UEs successfully established data sessions on the intended slice.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Complete failure of AMF node cluster resulting in an entire region losing 5G data connectivity. A cluster of AMF nodes responsible for a region went down simultaneously. All UEs in that region lost registration and data connectivity. There were no control plane responses from the AMF cluster for any incoming requests. The core network signaled a alarm for AMF availability.
output: The AMF cluster failure was due to a synchronization issue that caused a crash across all nodes after a configuration update. Troubleshooting involved rolling back the recent update and sequentially restarting each AMF node in the cluster. Additionally; logs were reviewed to pinpoint the configuration error. Once the cluster was restored and the faulty configuration corrected; UEs in the region re-registered and data connectivity was restored.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to handle encryption algorithm negotiation causing incompatible security settings and blocking data sessions. UEs are getting registered but are immediately dropping off when trying to use data. The security mode command process is failing for all UEs. AMF logs reveal that the encryption algorithm agreed with the UE is not supported by the user plane; causing the session to not proceed.
output: The root cause was an inconsistency in configured encryption algorithms between the AMF (and core) and the UEs. Specifically; the network allowed an algorithm that the user plane could not support. The resolution required updating the AMF allowed cipher list to exclude the unsupported algorithm. After updating the security settings on the AMF and reinitializing security mode procedures; UEs stayed connected and data sessions resumed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: outage of N11 interface between AMF and SMF blocking all 5G data session establishment in the network. All attempts to create new PDU sessions are failing across the network. UEs complete registration but cannot get an IP address for data. The SMF does not receive any session establishment requests from the AMF. AMF logs show repeated unsuccessful attempts to send messages over the N11 interface.
output: The N11 interface (AMF-SMF communication) was down due to a failed software update on the SMF. The root cause was a version incompatibility causing message handshake failure. Troubleshooting included reviewing interface logs and attempting a manual session setup trace. The fix involved rolling back the SMF update to restore compatibility with the AMF. Once N11 signaling was restored; UEs were able to establish data sessions again.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Frequent SCTP resets on N2 interface causing intermittent data session drops and service degradation. The connection between gNodeB and AMF keeps resetting periodically. UEs occasionally get disconnected or experience data session drops; especially when the SCTP reset occurs. NGAP logs from the gNodeB show repeated SCTP re-establishment procedures throughout the day.
output: The cause of the issue was network instability leading to SCTP heartbeat failures. The resolution steps included checking physical link quality and reducing SCTP heartbeat interval sensitivity on both AMF and gNB to tolerate brief outages. After adjusting network link stability and SCTP parameters; the frequency of resets decreased and the data sessions stabilized.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Partial failure in AMF to SMF communication leading to some UEs being unable to establish data sessions. Some UEs can register and use data normally; while others cannot establish data sessions. The failing UEs are associated with a specific data network name (DNN). AMF logs show that session requests for that DNN are not answered by any SMF. Other DNNs are working fine.
output: This issue was caused by a misconfiguration where a particular DNN was not mapped to an available SMF on the AMF. Troubleshooting involved verifying the DNN to SMF configuration on the AMF. Engineers updated the configuration to include the missing DNN mapping and reloaded the configuration. Following the fix; UEs using that DNN were able to establish data sessions successfully.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to assign a temporary ID properly causing UEs to lose connectivity when moving to idle state. UEs can initially use data services; but after going idle and then attempting to resume (paging) they fail to re-establish the data connection. The AMF logs show unusual entries where the UE context cannot be found for paging. NAS messages for service request are not being handled for these UEs.
output: The root cause was an issue in the AMF handling of temporary identifiers (like 5G-GUTI assignments). When UEs transitioned to idle; the identifier was not properly stored; making the AMF unable to page them. Troubleshooting steps included analyzing the paging procedure logs and verifying the GUTI allocation mechanism. The solution involved applying a patch to fix the GUTI allocation bug. Once applied; UEs could successfully resume data sessions after idle mode.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Excessive NAS signaling from a faulty UE causing AMF performance issues and data delays for other UEs. One misbehaving UE continuously sends registration requests and other NAS messages. The AMF becomes busy dealing with this single UE; leading to slower response times for others. Other UEs see delays in PDU session setup and occasional timeouts. AMF logs are flooded with repeat messages from the same UE.
output: This was a denial-of-service type scenario caused by a faulty or malicious UE. The AMF was saturated with repetitive NAS signaling. The immediate step was to blacklist the offending UE identity at the AMF to stop processing its requests. Network monitoring and NAS logs were used to identify the UE. After filtering out the UE; the AMF load normalized and data session setup times for other users returned to normal.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF node interface IP changed unexpectedly leading to gNodeB not being able to connect; impacting data services. The gNodeB suddenly cannot reach the AMF. UEs under that gNodeB lose data connectivity. Investigation shows the AMF N2 interface IP is not matching what the gNodeB is configured to use. NGAP setup messages are failing as a result.
output: The root cause was an unintended IP address change on the AMF N2 interface. The gNB was still trying the old IP; causing a connection failure. The resolution involved updating the gNB configuration with the new AMF IP (or reverting the AMF IP change). Once the IP mismatch was resolved and the SCTP associations re-established; the gNB successfully connected and data services were restored for its UEs.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Faulty timer configuration on AMF causing premature session releases and data interruptions. Some UEs experience unexpected drops in their data sessions shortly after establishing them. It appears the network is releasing connections too early. AMF logs reveal that a session release procedure is being triggered after a fixed short interval; affecting multiple UEs.
output: The issue stemmed from an incorrectly configured timer on the AMF for the active data session (possibly an idle or inactivity timer). The timer was set too aggressively short. Troubleshooting involved reviewing timer settings in the AMF configuration. The fix was to adjust the timer to the correct value as per standards. After updating the configuration and restarting the AMF to apply changes; UEs no longer experienced premature session releases.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to update SMF on user plane changes leading to stale paths and data session hiccups after handover. After a handover between gNodeBs; some UEs experience a brief loss of data connectivity. In these cases; the data path was not updated promptly. The SMF logs show that it did not receive the handover notification from the AMF in time; leading to a delay in user plane path switch.
output: The cause was an AMF signaling delay in informing the SMF of the new gNB for the UE after handover. The resolution was to check the AMF event notification settings and timers for the N2 handover procedure. By tuning the handover signaling timer and ensuring the AMF quickly sends the N2 relocation complete message to the SMF; the delay was eliminated. Subsequent handovers did not result in data path issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF memory leak issue causing gradual degradation of data session handling and eventual partial outages. The AMF performs normally after a fresh restart; but over time it starts to slow down. UEs increasingly see delays in registration and session setup. Eventually the AMF stops responding to some requests; causing a partial outage for data services. Memory usage on the AMF is observed to grow continuously.
output: The problem was a memory leak in the AMF software. Over time it exhausted resources; leading to degraded performance. Troubleshooting included monitoring memory over time and analyzing core dumps. The short-term solution was to perform controlled restarts of the AMF at off-peak times to restore service. The long-term resolution involved applying a vendor patch to fix the memory leak. After the patch; the AMF could handle prolonged operation without degradation.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: One gNodeB not configured in the AMF allowed list causing all UEs under that gNodeB to have no data service. UEs from a particular cell site are not able to register or use data; while others in the network are fine. The gNodeB is new and shows that it cannot complete the NGAP setup with the AMF. The AMF logs show an unknown gNodeB trying to connect which is being rejected.
output: The issue was that the new gNodeB was not added to the AMF configuration; so the AMF rejected its connection. To fix this; the network team added the gNodeB details (such as its identifier and IP info) to the AMF allowed configuration and then reinitialized the connection. After updating the AMF with the new site information; the gNodeB successfully connected and its UEs could register and access data services.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Misconfigured quality of service parameters leading to some UEs experiencing reduced data throughput. Not all UEs are affected; but those on a certain plan or slice see very low data rates. The core network is up and sessions are established; but throughput is throttled unexpectedly. AMF logs show that for those UEs the assigned QoS values are incorrect; causing the network to limit bandwidth.
output: The cause was a misconfiguration of QoS profiles in the AMF or SMF for that particular subscriber group. The AMF was associating the wrong QoS profile for those UEs due to a configuration mix-up. Troubleshooting involved verifying the subscription data and QoS settings in UDM and the corresponding configuration in the AMF and SMF. The team corrected the QoS configuration to match the intended profiles. Once updated; the affected UEs saw normal data throughput.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Incompatible NAS protocol extension used by UEs causing AMF to drop messages and some UEs failing to get data service. A specific model of 5G UE cannot get data service. They appear to register; but the PDU session setup never completes. The AMF debug logs show it is dropping an unrecognized IE (Information Element) in a NAS message from those UEs. Other UEs not using this extension are unaffected.
output: The issue was an incompatibility with a NAS protocol extension that the AMF software did not support. As a result it ignored or rejected PDU session requests from those UEs. The resolution was to update the AMF software to a version that supports the new NAS extensions or apply a patch to handle unknown IEs gracefully. After the update; the AMF could process the messages correctly and the affected UEs were able to establish data sessions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF instance out of sync in a multi-AMF environment resulting in inconsistent UE context and data session continuity issues. In an area served by multiple AMF instances; some UEs lose data connectivity when they move between areas. It seems their context is not found on the new AMF. Some UEs have to re-register completely; causing data session interruption. Logs indicate that context transfer between AMFs did not occur for those UEs.
output: The root cause was an issue in the AMF context transfer mechanism. One AMF was not properly forwarding UE context to its peer during inter-AMF mobility due to a config mismatch on the interface used for AMF-to-AMF communication. Troubleshooting involved reviewing the AMF Xn or N14 interface configuration for context transfer. The solution was to correct the configuration and test the context transfer procedure. After fixing the peer communication settings; UEs moved between AMF areas without losing their data sessions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF cannot process downlink data notification from SMF leading to paging failures and missed downlink data for idle UEs. When downlink data arrives for idle UEs; the SMF notifies the AMF to page the UE but some UEs are not receiving pages. The SMF logs show that notifications were sent. The AMF shows no page attempts for those UEs. As a result these UEs do not get the incoming data until they reattach on their own.
output: The cause was a bug in the AMF paging handling. The AMF was silently dropping downlink data notification messages under certain conditions (like if the UE was in a transitional state). The troubleshooting included tracing the paging interface (N2) and verifying if the AMF initiated paging. After identifying the faulty logic; a patch was applied to the AMF software. Following the fix; the AMF reliably triggered paging for idle UEs with downlink data and they resumed receiving data promptly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Misrouted NGAP messages due to incorrect AMF ID causing signaling confusion and data session setup delays. In the network; some signaling messages from a gNodeB were mistakenly routed to a wrong AMF instance. This caused confusion in the control plane; where a UE initial message was handled by one AMF and subsequent messages by another. The user eventually got service but only after delays and reattempts.
output: This was caused by an incorrect AMF identifier configured in one gNodeB causing it to sometimes send to the wrong AMF. The resolution involved correcting the AMF identifier and address in the gNodeB configuration. Network logs and the core routing tables were examined to identify the misrouting. Once the configuration was fixed; all initial UE messages consistently reached the correct AMF and data session setups became smooth without delays.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF not releasing old context causing new session setup to fail for returning UEs. UEs that had previously detached and are attempting to reattach cannot get a data session. The AMF appears to consider that the UEs already have an active session and rejects new attempts. Logs show context for those UE IDs still present and not cleared properly upon detach.
output: The cause was that the AMF did not fully clear UE context after detachment due to a software bug. Residual context made the AMF think the UEs were duplicates. The fix involved cleaning up stale contexts by restarting the AMF context management service and applying a patch that corrects the detach procedure. After deploying the fix; UEs were able to reattach and establish new data sessions without issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Signaling storm during peak hours causing delayed processing of NAS messages and data session timeouts. During peak usage; the network experiences a surge in signaling. The AMF has a backlog of NAS messages. Some UEs time out waiting for replies; leading to failed data session setups. Monitoring shows high signaling traffic and some NAS procedures taking unusually long to complete.
output: The AMF was experiencing congestion under heavy signaling load. The immediate mitigation was to distribute UEs to additional AMF nodes to balance the load. Operators also performed database optimization for the AMF internal procedures to handle high traffic. Additionally; unnecessary periodic update messages from UEs were configured to be less frequent to reduce load. After these measures; the AMF handled peak traffic more efficiently and session timeout issues subsided.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Incorrect APN (DNN) configuration preventing certain devices from getting a 5G data session. A group of devices using a specific APN (now called DNN in 5G) cannot establish data sessions. They register fine; but the PDU session fails immediately. Other APNs are working for the same UEs if tried. The AMF logs indicate no available session routing for the requested DNN.
output: The cause was a missing or incorrect configuration for that DNN on the AMF and SMF. Essentially; the network did not know how to route sessions for that APN. Troubleshooting steps involved reviewing the configured DNN list and slice configuration on the AMF. The missing configuration was added and the SMF was configured accordingly. After correcting the APN configuration and syncing it across AMF and SMF; the devices were able to establish data sessions on that APN.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF to AUSF interface issue resulting in new UEs failing to attach due to authentication not completing. New UEs attempting to attach to the network are failing at the authentication stage. The NAS authentication request is sent but never successfully completes. AMF logs suggest timeouts waiting for a response from the AUSF. Meanwhile; existing connected UEs continue unaffected.
output: This was caused by an interface issue between the AMF and AUSF (authentication server). The connection was mistakenly blocked by a firewall policy after a maintenance change. The troubleshooting included checking the communication path to AUSF and finding the drop. The resolution was to correct the firewall rules to allow AMF-AUSF traffic and verify connectivity. Once the interface was restored; the authentication procedures succeeded and new UEs could attach and use data.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Handover failure due to AMF not honoring a configuration update leading to dropped data sessions during inter-cell handovers. When UEs move from one cell to another; a significant number of calls drop. The handover request is initiated but fails. The gNodeB logs indicate the target cell did not receive necessary context from the AMF. The AMF had a new configuration for handover that was recently introduced.
output: The issue was the AMF not properly using updated handover configuration (possibly a new parameter was introduced but not fully activated). The resolution involved rolling back to the previous stable handover settings on the AMF. Engineers performed thorough testing on a staging environment to identify the mismatch. After reverting the configuration; handovers proceeded normally and data sessions were maintained across cell changes.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF misinterprets a 5G NAS message leading to session establishment errors for certain UEs. Certain UEs send a slightly different form of a NAS message during session establishment. The AMF log indicates it flags an error upon receiving those messages. These UEs fail to get an IP address for data; although others in the same area do fine. The issue is reproducible with those specific UEs or firmware version.
output: This problem was due to the AMF software misinterpreting an otherwise standards-compliant NAS message variant. After capturing the NAS messages and analyzing them; it was determined that the AMF NAS stack had a parsing issue. The resolution required a software update or patch from the vendor to fix the NAS parsing logic. Once the fix was applied; the previously failing UEs could establish data sessions normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF slow in releasing resources causing delays in new data session setup after old sessions end. After some UEs disconnect; they and others attempting new sessions face delays. It looks like the network is at capacity even though UEs left. AMF resource logs show that some session context entries remain marked as active even after disconnection. This hogs session capacity and makes new session setups wait or fail.
output: The cause was that the AMF was not promptly releasing session resources due to a delay in clearing contexts. The troubleshooting step was to confirm via logs and management interface that contexts were stuck. A temporary fix was to manually clear the stale contexts via management commands. The permanent fix involved a patch to ensure the AMF immediately clears session state on termination. After the fix; resource counts freed up properly and new sessions were established without delay.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Partial outage due to one AMF in cluster failing some UEs experience service interruption while others remain unaffected. The network uses multiple AMF instances. One of them failed unexpectedly due to a hardware fault. UEs connected to that particular AMF lost data service; whereas UEs on other AMFs continued normally. Monitoring shows one AMF node down and not responding to its UEs on N2 and N1.
output: The failure of a single AMF node caused a partial outage. The resolution steps included shifting the affected UEs to a healthy AMF by triggering a re-registration for those UEs. Engineers also replaced the faulty hardware and brought the failed AMF node back online. Improvements were identified to automate failover so that UEs automatically reconnect to a standby AMF if their serving AMF goes down.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF overloaded interface queue causing signaling messages to be dropped under high load. Under heavy load; some NAS and NGAP messages do not get processed by the AMF. This leads to missing signals such as a delay in Registration Accept or PDU session setup messages. UEs under load conditions see failures that clear up after load reduces. The AMF internal message queue is observed growing during the issue.
output: The AMF was dropping messages because its internal queues were overflowing under high load. The troubleshooting included monitoring internal metrics and traffic patterns. The solution involved increasing the queue capacity and optimizing the message processing threads within the AMF. Additionally; load balancing more UEs to other AMF nodes helped. After these changes; the AMF could handle high traffic without dropping signaling messages and UEs no longer experienced failures during peak load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: NAS encryption mismatch leading to some UEs failing the security mode and dropping connection. A subset of UEs (often older models) cannot complete the security mode procedure during registration. They get rejected and cannot use data. Logs show the AMF sending a security mode command and then a failure occurring. Those UEs likely only support older encryption algorithms that the network initially did not prefer.
output: The issue was an encryption algorithm mismatch. The AMF was picking an algorithm not supported by those UEs. Troubleshooting involved analyzing the security capabilities exchanged during NAS signaling. The fix was to adjust the AMF security configuration to include compatibility with older algorithms. After updating the allowed algorithms on the AMF; the previously failing UEs passed the security procedure and gained access to data services.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Delayed NGAP UE Context Release causing slower cleanup of sessions and temporary resource strain. After UEs disconnect normally; the gNodeB sends a UE Context Release command to the AMF but the AMF takes longer than usual to free the context. While not directly impacting users who already disconnected; it slightly delays those resources being available for new connections. This issue is mostly noticed in logs and by monitoring system performance.
output: The issue was and related to a slow handling of context release at the AMF. The root cause was a small bug in the context release timer handling. The resolution was to fine-tune the context release process in the AMF software. This was done by applying a patch to improve the handling of the release message. Post patch; context release became immediate eliminating any resource strain.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: configuration mismatch in AMF paging settings leading to slightly delayed responses to downlink data triggers. Idle UEs are mostly working fine; but occasionally there is a slight delay before they respond to downlink data. Paging is happening; but the timing seems a bit off. It does not stop service; but it is not as prompt as expected. This is noticed only in detailed testing scenarios and not by end users.
output: This issue was due to a configuration mismatch in paging timers between the AMF and gNodeB. The values were not aligned; causing a delay. Troubleshooting involved reviewing the timer settings on both sides and logs of paging response times. The fix was to adjust the AMF paging timer to match the expected value. After synchronization of timer settings; paging response was prompt resolving the slight delays observed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Log overflow on AMF causing negligible performance impact but triggering alarms. The AMF generates a large volume of debug logs when a certain NAS message is processed. This caused a log partition to fill up but did not directly impact data sessions. However; it triggered an alarm and could have led to issues if left unchecked.
output: The root cause was excessive logging for a specific event. The resolution involved changing the logging level for the verbose event on the AMF to reduce unnecessary log volume. The logs were also rotated and cleared. This prevented any potential future performance issues and cleared the alarm. Data services were not directly affected and no user impact was observed aside from the maintenance alert.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Single UE with faulty behavior causing AMF warnings no significant impact on overall data service. Logs show repeated errors. One particular UE is triggering unusual NAS messages that the AMF flags as errors. The UE still gets service after retries and other UEs are fine. This results in error logs in the AMF but no noticeable service impact. It is essentially a single-device anomaly.
output: This was a issue isolated to one UE. The AMF logged error messages due to that UE atypical behavior. Troubleshooting was minimal since impact was negligible: the team monitored the UE activity and advised a firmware update on the device. The resolution was to update the UE software after which it behaved normally. The AMF no longer reported errors for that UE resolving the anomaly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: packet loss on N2 interface causing occasional retransmissions but minimal impact on data experience. Some NGAP messages require retransmission due to packet loss between the gNodeB and AMF. Users might experience a slight delay during those retransmissions; but the system recovers automatically. This is observed in monitoring tools but does not noticeably degrade user experience except for a slight increase in signaling latency.
output: The packet loss was likely due to transient network issues on the N2 link. Troubleshooting included checking link statistics and ensuring error correction mechanisms were in place. The solution was to monitor the link and work with the transport team to improve link reliability. Adjusting the SCTP parameters to better handle loss (like a slightly longer timeout before retransmission) also helped. The outcome was that even if occasional loss occurred it was handled gracefully maintaining service quality.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Non-urgent AMF alarm due to infrequent NAS decode error with no user impact but requires attention in logs. Rarely; the AMF logs an error decoding a NAS message from a UE. This triggers a low-severity alarm for investigation. The UE in question usually retries and succeeds; so users do not report any problem. It is a sporadic issue seen perhaps in one out of thousands of messages.
output: Since the issue was infrequent and did not impact service; it was treated as a bug. Engineers collected the rare NAS messages for analysis. The cause was a corner-case message format that the AMF did not fully support. As a resolution; they included this case in the next software update. Meanwhile; the alarm threshold was adjusted so that such sporadic errors did not trigger alarms unless they became frequent. The fix in the software later eliminated these decode errors entirely.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UE location update anomalies causing hiccups in service continuity when moving between areas. On rare occasions; a UE moving between tracking areas experiences a slight delay in reestablishing its data session. The issue is noticed as a brief hiccup in connectivity. AMF logs show that the location update procedure took longer than usual for those instances; though it eventually completes.
output: This hiccup was due to the AMF taking extra time to update location information in one of the internal databases. Troubleshooting involved checking the tracking area update (TAU) handling and the latency in updating the context. The team optimized the database calls within the AMF to speed up the update. After this optimization; the location update occurred faster and the brief connectivity hiccups were no longer observed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Suboptimal parameter setting for AMF load balancing resulting in uneven load but minimal impact on service. The network has multiple AMFs; but one was handling a disproportionately high number of UEs. This caused that AMF to run near capacity while others were lightly loaded. There was no immediate impact on data sessions; but there were concerns of a potential issue if load increased further. delays were occasionally observed in the busiest AMF responses.
output: The cause was suboptimal configuration of the load-balancing algorithm for assigning UEs to AMFs. Troubleshooting involved reviewing how UEs are assigned to each AMF and noticing the imbalance. The team fine-tuned the load balancing parameters and; if available; enabled dynamic load rebalancing features. After these changes; new UEs were distributed more evenly across AMFs. The overloaded node response times improved; eliminating the delays and reducing future risk.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Temporary AMF service process hang causing a brief pause in handling requests but self-resolves. At one instance; the AMF paused briefly (for a few seconds) in processing requests due to a background process hang. A few NAS messages queued up but were processed once the hang cleared. Some UEs might have experienced a slight delay in response during that moment; but service continued normally right after.
output: This was a transient glitch in the AMF where a background thread became unresponsive for a short time. The situation resolved on its own; but engineers investigated logs to ensure it was not a symptom of a bigger issue. The root cause was traced to a routine maintenance task (like stats aggregation) that took too long. The resolution was to optimize that routine to run more efficiently during off-peak times. No further action was needed as it did not recur after adjustments.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: license limit warning on AMF approaching user capacity but not yet impacting service. The AMF is licensed for a certain number of UEs and that threshold is nearly reached. A warning is raised indicating the system is nearing capacity. Current users are not affected and data sessions continue normally; but if growth continues new attachments might be refused later. This is observed in system warnings and capacity logs.
output: Though service is not yet impacted; the resolution involves proactive capacity management. The team plans an upgrade to increase the AMF licensed capacity. In the interim; they ensure no new large deployments connect to that AMF. Monitoring continues for any sign of actual refusal. After the license upgrade is applied; the warning clears and the AMF can handle more UEs preventing any future capacity-related issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Inconsistency in AMF stored subscriber info leading to a issue where some UEs needed to reattach to update their profile. A handful of UEs that changed their subscription package were still being treated under the old profile by the AMF for a short time. As a result; their data rate was not updated until they re-registered. This did not cause loss of service; just a short delay in applying new service parameters.
output: This issue was caused by a caching delay in the AMF retrieving updated subscriber information from the UDM. The resolution was to clear or refresh the cache on the AMF more frequently for subscriber data changes. Once the caching policy was adjusted; any subscription changes were reflected almost immediately for connected UEs removing the need for them to reattach to get updated profiles.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: mismatch in supported frequency bands causing certain UEs to connect on fallback 4G instead of 5G. Some UEs in a fringe area are not staying on 5G and revert to 4G. While not a direct fault in data service; it means those UEs do not utilize 5G data speeds in that area. The AMF logs show that these UEs often deregister from 5G after failing to find a supported band; which might indicate an AMF configuration for coverage or bands that is slightly off.
output: This turned out to be related to network configuration rather than an AMF fault. The band configuration broadcast (that the AMF indirectly controls via policies) was not updated for a new frequency. The fix involved updating the network band support configuration so that those UEs recognize 5G coverage properly. Once updated; the UEs remained on 5G and utilized 5G data resolving the fallback issue.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SNSSAI configuration discrepancy leading to non-warnings in AMF logs with no user impact. The AMF log contains warnings that a particular single-network slice selection assistance information (SNSSAI) value was received but not recognized. The UEs with that slice still attach using a default slice; so service continues. This only triggers a warning in logs and is likely due to a test slice value present on a few SIMs that is not configured in the network.
output: Engineers verified that the SNSSAI in question was not intended for production use. The resolution was simply to add a configuration on the AMF to recognize and map that test SNSSAI to a default handling or to instruct the UEs to not request it. This eliminated the warning. Since it was a non-issue with no user impact; it was resolved in a routine maintenance update by updating the slice configuration table on the AMF.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UE deregistration procedure edge case causing a benign error message in AMF but session ends normally. When some UEs disconnect (deregister) an error is logged indicating the context was not found; even though the session was already terminated properly. There is no effect on service as it occurs when the UE is leaving anyway. It is an edge case in the deregistration sequence observed occasionally.
output: This glitch was due to the AMF trying to clean up a session that was already cleaned by a parallel process. Essentially; a timing issue in handling deregistration. The fix was to adjust the deregistration handling routine to better synchronize context deletion. After applying the fix in the AMF software; the error messages ceased. There was no user-facing impact and this purely improved the cleanliness of the logs and procedures.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Monitoring tool reports inconsistency in AMF metrics with no actual impact on user sessions. The operations monitoring system flagged that the AMF reported number of active sessions briefly went negative or inconsistent for a short time. This did not reflect reality and no actual sessions were impacted. It appears to be a calculation or reporting glitch on the AMF metrics interface.
output: This was a issue in the metrics reporting module of the AMF. Engineers cross-checked actual session counts to ensure no real issue. The resolution was to correct the metrics calculation in a software update. Applying the update fixed the inconsistency. There was never any user impact and the monitoring tool no longer reports false anomalies.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Rare race condition in AMF message handling leading to an occasional delay but auto-corrects on retry. Under a very specific sequence of events; an initial registration message and a nearly simultaneous service request collided in the AMF processing causing one of them to be delayed. The UE had to retry once which then succeeded. This happened extremely rarely and was identified during stress testing.
output: Through intensive log analysis; a rare race condition was identified in the AMF handling of concurrent NAS procedures. The developers provided a patch to better serialize these events. The fix was applied to ensure one procedure completes before the next begins in such scenarios. After the patch; testing showed that the collision no longer occurred. Since it was a timing issue no regular user likely noticed it; but it was resolved to strengthen system reliability.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Transient data path setup delay where initial attempt fails but second attempt succeeds resulting in a startup lag. Occasionally; a UE first attempt to establish a data session after registering might not complete but a second immediate attempt does. This results in a few extra seconds before the UE gets an IP address. Logs show that the initial PDU session resource setup timed out; possibly because the gNB did not respond in time to the AMF request.
output: The transient delay was likely due to a timing issue between the AMF and gNB. Troubleshooting included checking the PDU session resource setup procedure in traces. The team increased the timeout slightly on the AMF for that procedure to give the gNB more time. Additionally; they optimized gNB response performance. After these adjustments; the initial attempt succeeded consistently removing the startup lag for data sessions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Misleading alarm due to outdated AMF neighbor config triggering a false positive fault alert with no actual user impact. An alarm was raised indicating an AMF neighbor link failure. However; all UEs and services were working normally. It turned out that a neighboring AMF reference was left in the configuration from a previous setup and was not actually in use. The system misinterpreted its absence as a fault.
output: The alarm was a false positive caused by stale configuration. The resolution was to clean up the AMF configuration by removing references to the non-existent neighbor. Engineers confirmed through audits that the neighbor was not needed. Once removed; the alarm cleared. There was no effect on users; but the cleanup helps prevent confusion and keeps the fault monitoring signals accurate.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UE count threshold nearly exceeded on one AMF causing a alarm but managed by shifting some load. One AMF came close to its supported UE count threshold raising a warning. A handful of new UEs trying to attach were temporarily redirected to another AMF. Users saw no downtime; but the distribution had to be adjusted. System logs indicated that the threshold was reached and load balancing kicked in.
output: This capacity alarm was addressed by proactively redistributing some UEs to other AMFs in the network. The team also planned a capacity upgrade. The resolution included verifying that the load balancing function correctly moved some UEs to alleviate the load. After the shift and a scheduled addition of a new AMF instance; the UE count per AMF was well under threshold and the warning cleared. Service continuity was maintained throughout.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Non-interface statistic error where an AMF interface counter froze not affecting service but requiring a reset. The AMF management interface stopped updating one of its statistics counters (for example; the counter for N1 messages). Operations teams noticed the number stayed constant; which was clearly incorrect; but all actual signaling was working fine. It appears to be just a reporting issue in the statistics module.
output: This non-issue was resolved by simply restarting the statistics service of the AMF. The cause was likely a bug causing the counter to freeze. After the restart; the counter resumed updating correctly. A fix was planned in a future release to prevent the counter from freezing. This did not affect any user traffic so it remained a low priority issue that was resolved during routine maintenance.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Testing mode left enabled on AMF leading to verbose behavior with network impact. After some maintenance; the AMF was left in a special debug or testing mode inadvertently. In this mode; it responded to certain test NAS sequences more slowly (since it was collecting extra data). A few UEs experienced delays in initial attach. The mistake was caught when noticing unusual test logs in the system.
output: The resolution was straightforward: disable the testing mode on the AMF. The root cause was human error in forgetting to revert the AMF to normal operation mode after maintenance. Once normal mode was restored; the AMF stopped the verbose behavior and performance returned to full speed. The attach delays disappeared and the extraneous logs ceased.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF repeatedly crashes and restarts in a loop after a software update leading to periodic complete disruptions of 5G data services across the network. Following a recent software update; the AMF node is observed to crash and reboot frequently (for example; every several minutes). Each time it restarts; all UEs lose registration and data sessions drop; then some recover until the next crash. The cycle causes a continual up-and-down data service experience.
output: The root cause was a software bug introduced in the latest update causing an unhandled exception. Troubleshooting involved analyzing core dump files and identifying the offending update module. The immediate solution was to roll back to the previous stable software version. After rollback; the AMF stayed online without crashing. The vendor provided a patched version to address the bug which was tested and applied to permanently resolve the issue.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF security certificate expires causing it to reject or fail communication with other core network functions and resulting in network-wide attach failures. Suddenly; all new registration and PDU session setup attempts are failing. Other network functions (like SMF UDM) log that the AMF is not responding or the connection is not authenticated. Upon inspection; the AMF services show errors establishing secure connections on service-based interfaces.
output: The cause was an expired digital certificate used by the AMF for secure communication with core network services. The resolution required obtaining and installing an updated valid certificate on the AMF. Administrators updated the certificate and restarted the affected AMF services to re-establish trust with other network functions. Once updated; the AMF could successfully communicate and UEs were able to attach and set up data sessions again.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF license expires causing the AMF to stop accepting new registrations and data session requests across the network. The network suddenly cannot accept any new UEs for data service. Registered users remain connected for a while; but no new attachments succeed. The AMF logs indicate it has entered an unauthorized state and is dropping incoming requests. This coincides with the license expiry date.
output: The outage was due to the AMF software license expiring which caused it to block new sessions. The resolution was to immediately apply a renewed license to the AMF. Once the new license key was installed and the AMF software re-validated; normal operation resumed. Additionally; processes were put in place to monitor license validity and renew licenses well before expiry to prevent future occurrences.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF sends mass deregistration to all UEs due to a malfunction causing a complete drop of all 5G data sessions in the network. Without warning; all active UEs lost connectivity simultaneously. The UEs indicated they were deregistered from the network. Control plane logs showed that the AMF issued deregistration messages to all connected UEs. This happened in error and was not due to any planned operation.
output: The incident was traced to a malfunction in the AMF triggered by a faulty script or bug that treated all UEs as invalid. The resolution started with stopping the offending process to prevent continuous deregistration. Then; engineers had UEs reattach by resetting the AMF and broadcasting a re-registration request. A software patch was applied to remove the erroneous trigger. After these steps; UEs could register again and data sessions were re-established. Safeguards were added to prevent global deregistration commands from executing improperly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Subscriber database corruption at UDM causing the AMF to receive invalid subscriber data and resulting in widespread data session establishment failures. Many UEs are unable to complete data session setup because subscription data retrieval fails or returns incorrect information. The AMF receives responses from the UDM that are either empty or malformed for multiple subscribers. This leads to the AMF rejecting session requests since it cannot validate service permissions.
output: The root cause was a corruption in the subscriber database used by the UDM which in turn gave the AMF bad data. The resolution involved restoring the subscriber database from a recent backup and resynchronizing it with the UDM. During troubleshooting; the AMF logs and UDM queries were analyzed to identify the corruption issue. After the database restore; the AMF began receiving correct subscriber profiles and UEs were able to establish data sessions normally. Additional database integrity checks were implemented to catch such issues early.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: DDoS attack floods the AMF with signaling resulting in an overload that knocks out 5G data services for many subscribers. The network experiences a sudden surge of malicious signaling traffic aimed at the AMF. NAS registration requests and other signaling from thousands of spoofed or compromised sources bombard the AMF. Legitimate UEs cannot get timely responses; leading to widespread registration failures and dropped sessions.
output: Facing a denial-of-service attack; immediate measures were taken to mitigate the traffic. Network firewalls were configured to block the offending source ranges and rate-limit NAS requests to the AMF. The AMF was restarted to clear the overload. Concurrently; a traffic filter was deployed to distinguish legitimate traffic from the flood. Once mitigations were in place; the AMF load decreased to normal levels and genuine users regained access. Further security enhancements were implemented including signaling storm detection and scrubbing systems to protect the AMF from future DDoS attacks.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Firewall misconfiguration blocks N2 interface traffic cutting off all gNodeBs from the AMF and causing a complete service outage. All gNodeBs in the network suddenly lost connection to the AMF over the N2 interface. This occurred right after a firewall policy update in the core network. UEs could not register or maintain connections; effectively causing a total loss of service. The gNBs showed SCTP link down alarms towards the AMF.
output: The problem was identified as a firewall rule that erroneously started blocking SCTP traffic on the AMF N2 port. The immediate fix was to rollback the firewall change; restoring connectivity. Troubleshooting included checking network firewall logs and configurations to pinpoint the block. After removing the offending rule; the SCTP associations were re-established successfully. All gNodeBs reconnected to the AMF and UEs were able to register again. The firewall change process was revised to include testing connectivity for interfaces in the future.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF configuration file corruption after reboot resulting in the AMF coming online with default settings and failing to serve 5G UEs. Following a routine restart of the AMF; the node failed to properly handle registrations. It seemed to have lost its configured data (like PLMN and slice configurations) and was acting as if it were a fresh install. UEs could not register and gNodeBs reported unknown network parameters. Essentially; the AMF was not recognizing the network identity and configuration.
output: It turned out the AMF configuration file got corrupted and it loaded with fallback default settings. The resolution was to reload a backup of the correct configuration onto the AMF. Engineers identified the issue by noticing default IDs and parameters in AMF logs. Once the backup config was applied and the AMF was restarted; it regained the correct network settings. UEs were then able to register and access data. Steps were taken to verify file system integrity and prevent future corruption such as using redundant config storage.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Timing bug triggers mass failure at a specific time causing the AMF to drop sessions due to a software error when a certain timer or counter resets. At a particular time (for instance; midnight or a counter rollover point) a significant number of UEs were suddenly disconnected. This coincided with a periodic event inside the AMF. Many UEs had to re-register after this time. The issue was repeatable at the same interval indicating a systematic timing problem.
output: The cause was a software bug in the AMF triggered by a timer overflow or scheduled routine that malfunctioned. Engineers used timestamped logs to correlate the failure to a specific scheduled task in the AMF. The resolution involved applying a software patch that fixed the timer handling logic. Until the patch was ready; the team staggered the AMF internal timers as a temporary workaround to avoid simultaneous impact. After the patch installation; the timed event no longer caused any session drops.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Network function discovery failure (NRF issue) leading the AMF to be unable to find core services like SMF or AUSF and causing new session failures. The AMF relies on the network repository function (NRF) to discover addresses of other network functions. During an outage of the NRF or a registration failure; the AMF could not retrieve the service endpoints for the SMF and AUSF. As a result; new attach and session setup procedures started failing because the AMF did not know where to send requests. Ongoing sessions were not immediately affected; but any new or transitioning UEs experienced service failure.
output: The resolution was to restore the network function discovery mechanism. Engineers quickly identified that the NRF was down due to a fault. They restarted the NRF and ensured it had the latest registry of network functions. In parallel; a temporary static configuration was loaded into the AMF to allow it to reach services without NRF. Once NRF was back up and the AMF confirmed the addresses of SMF and AUSF; normal session establishment resumed. To prevent recurrence; the team implemented a redundant NRF setup and cached NF information within the AMF for short periods.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Missing N26 interface for interworking causing 5G to 4G fallback attempts to fail and dropping data service when UEs leave 5G coverage. In areas where UEs transition from 5G SA to 4G (LTE) coverage; calls or data sessions are dropping instead of handing over. UEs cannot fall back to LTE data resulting in a loss of connectivity until they reattach via 4G separately. The AMF logs show attempts to perform inter-system handover but there is no response or coordination with any 4G core node.
output: It was found that the N26 interface (for 5G-4G interworking) was not configured or enabled; so the AMF could not communicate with the 4G core (MME). The resolution involved enabling and properly configuring the N26 interface on the AMF and ensuring the 4G core was prepared for interworking. Once configured; the AMF successfully coordinated with the MME allowing seamless fallback to LTE. UEs then experienced smooth data continuity when moving out of 5G coverage.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Roaming flag misconfiguration in AMF causing home subscribers to be treated as roamers and denying their data sessions inadvertently. A portion of subscribers from the home network are being denied data service because the core thinks they are roaming (and possibly not authorized). The AMF records show it marking some local IMSIs with roaming status due to an incorrect parameter. These UEs get registered but their PDU session establishment is rejected under policy.
output: The issue was traced to a misconfigured parameter in the AMF that tagged certain subscribers with the wrong home network identity. Troubleshooting involved reviewing the AMF PLMN and IMSI range configuration. The configuration was corrected so that those subscribers are recognized as home network users. After the change; affected UEs were able to establish data sessions normally. The team also verified all subscriber identification settings to ensure no other ranges were misclassified.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Tracking area code not recognized by AMF leading to UEs in a certain area being unable to register for data service. UEs in one geographical area consistently fail to register on 5G. The gNodeB in that area is broadcasting a tracking area code that the AMF does not have configured. As a result when UEs from that area attempt registration; the AMF rejects them because it sees an unknown tracking area identifier.
output: The root cause was that the tracking area code (TAC) for that region was missing in the AMF configuration. The resolution was to update the AMF allowed tracking area list to include the missing TAC. After updating and syncing the configuration; the AMF recognized the area and UEs from that region could register and receive data service. This fix restored connectivity for users in that area and the network team double-checked all configured TACs to prevent similar issues elsewhere.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM response delays causing slow or timed-out registration and session setup for some UEs. At times; UEs are experiencing very slow attach procedures or even failures. The AMF logs show that it is waiting unusually long for subscriber data from the UDM. Some requests time out; causing the AMF to drop the registration or session setup. This tends to happen during peak hours when many queries are being sent to the UDM.
output: The issue was identified as latency in the UDM response. It was overloaded and responding slowly.
