As an immediate workaround; the time-out values in the AMF were slightly increased to accommodate the delay reducing the drop rate. The longer-term fix was to optimize and upgrade the UDM to handle more queries. After the UDM improvements and configuration of additional UDM instances; the AMF received subscriber data more promptly and UEs no longer faced registration timeouts.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Bug with multiple PDU sessions per UE causing one session to drop when a second session is released for the same UE. UEs that establish two concurrent data sessions (for example one for general internet and one for a special service) experience an issue: if one session is disconnected by the user or network the remaining session also drops unexpectedly. The AMF and SMF logs for those UEs show that when one PDU session release completes; the context for the second session was also erroneously cleared.
output: This was determined to be a bug in how the AMF handled multiple active sessions for a single UE. The AMF was inadvertently tying the sessions together in its context management. Engineers reproduced the issue and a patch was developed to separate session contexts correctly. After applying the fix; releasing one PDU session no longer affected the other. Troubleshooting involved extensive log analysis and testing with UEs having multiple sessions to ensure the problem was resolved.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Clock synchronization issue between AMF and other nodes leading to authentication failures due to timestamp mismatches for some UEs. Some UEs fail authentication even with correct credentials; especially during certain periods. Investigation shows that the challenge-response procedure sometimes indicates a failure due to out-of-sync errors. The AMF logs and the AUSF (authentication server) logs hint at a time discrepancy in the generated authentication vectors.
output: It turned out that the AMF system clock was slightly out of sync (several seconds) with the AUSF and UDM. This caused the time-sensitive authentication tokens to appear expired or invalid. The resolution was to immediately resynchronize the AMF clock using NTP with the same time source as other core nodes. After synchronizing time; the authentication errors ceased. Additionally; monitoring was put in place to alert if any core network element clock drifts beyond an acceptable threshold to prevent such issues in the future.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: One SMF instance failure causing all UEs on a particular slice or DNN to lose data connectivity. The network supports multiple slices or DNNs; each potentially handled by different SMF instances. One of these SMF instances went down unexpectedly. UEs associated with that slice started losing data sessions; and new session setups for that slice failed. The AMF logs show repeated attempts to contact the specific SMF with no response; leading to timeouts for those session setups.
output: When the SMF instance handling that slice failed; its sessions could not be maintained. The resolution involved restarting the failed SMF and ensuring a standby SMF took over its load. The AMF configuration was also checked to verify that a backup route for session requests (to an alternate SMF) was in place. After the SMF was restored; the AMF successfully re-established sessions for the slice. To improve resilience; the procedure for automatic failover to a secondary SMF for that slice was tested and reinforced.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Network slice selection function (NSSF) misconfiguration resulting in the AMF failing to route UEs to the correct slice and some data sessions being rejected. Certain UEs are not being assigned to their requested network slice. For example; enterprise UEs requesting a dedicated slice are instead being attempted on the default slice and getting rejected due to policy. The AMF queries to the NSSF are returning errors or wrong information. This is causing slice-specific service failures.
output: It was determined that the NSSF had an incorrect configuration or incomplete data about available slices. The AMF was not getting proper guidance on slice selection. The fix involved correcting the slice configuration in the NSSF ‚Äì updating the mapping of S-NSSAIs to the appropriate core network endpoints. Once the NSSF was updated and the AMF was synchronized with the correct slice info; UEs were properly routed to the intended slice. The specific UEs that were failing could then establish data sessions on their slice. Additional testing was done to confirm slice selection works for all scenarios.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: gNodeB software incompatibility with NGAP updates causing one vendor gNodeB to fail registration procedures with the AMF. UEs connected to a particular vendor gNodeB are failing to register on the 5G core; while other gNodeBs (different vendor) in the network work fine. The failing scenario shows that after the UE initial message; the procedure halts. AMF logs indicate an error parsing an NGAP message from that gNodeB. The gNodeB might be using an outdated or slightly different NGAP format that the AMF latest version does not accept.
output: The cause was an incompatibility between the AMF NGAP implementation and the particular gNodeB software version. The AMF was expecting an Information Element that the gNodeB did not send (or formatted differently). Troubleshooting included capturing the NGAP messages and comparing them with expected formats. The resolution was two-fold: a temporary workaround on the AMF to relax the strict checking (allowing the message to be processed) and a coordination with the gNodeB vendor to update their software. Once the fix was applied; UEs on that gNodeB could register and use data services normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Session capacity configuration too low causing the AMF to reject new sessions after a certain number. This occurred even though resources were available. The network observed that after reaching a specific number of active sessions additional UEs trying to establish data sessions were being rejected. This limit was much lower than what the hardware could support. The AMF logs indicated it was enforcing a maximum session count and refusing new sessions once that threshold was hit treating it as if resources were exhausted.
output: The issue was a misconfigured parameter for maximum sessions on the AMF. It was set to a conservative number inappropriate for the deployment. Once identified; engineers updated the configuration to raise the limit to the correct level. After applying the new configuration and restarting the AMF service to pick up the changes; the artificial cap was removed. The AMF then allowed more sessions and UEs could attach and create data sessions beyond the old limit. Post-change; monitoring confirmed that the hardware was handling the increased load without issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Multi-PLMN support misconfigured resulting in subscribers of a second network being unable to receive service through the shared AMF. In a shared core scenario; the AMF was supposed to serve two different PLMN IDs (for two operators). Subscribers from the secondary PLMN were consistently failing to attach or get data service; whereas the primary PLMN users were fine. The failing subscribers IMSIs belong to a PLMN that the AMF did advertise support for; but something is not working in practice. The AMF is not completing the registration for those IMSIs.
output: The cause was a misconfiguration in the AMF multi-PLMN settings. The secondary PLMN identifiers were not fully provisioned (or a roaming agreement flag was missing). The team corrected the AMF configuration by adding the missing PLMN ID and associated parameters properly into the system. They then tested with test SIMs of that PLMN. After correction; the AMF successfully handled registrations for the second PLMN and those subscribers gained 5G data service. Documentation was updated to ensure multi-PLMN configuration steps are thoroughly followed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF erroneously triggers UE context release causing active data sessions to drop prematurely for some UEs. It was observed that on some occasions the AMF signaled a UE Context Release toward the gNodeB without a clear reason; leading to those UEs being disconnected even though they had active sessions. This happened intermittently; often shortly after a successful registration or session setup. The UEs were forced to reattach to resume service.
output: Investigation revealed a software bug where the AMF incorrectly determined that certain UEs were inactive or duplicate and sent a release. The resolution required a software patch to fix the UE context management logic. The team collected logs around the events and identified the erroneous trigger condition. After applying the patch; the AMF no longer sent unexpected release messages. UEs stayed connected as expected. Additionally; monitoring was put in place to catch if any unusual release events occur in the future.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Over-aggressive periodic registration timer causing UEs to be deregistered if they do not update fast enough; this interrupted data service. Some UEs are getting deregistered by the network while they are idle. It turns out the network is expecting them to perform periodic registration updates very frequently. UEs that do not send an update within that short interval are being removed from the AMF context meaning when they try to resume the network treats them as new attaches causing a break in ongoing data sessions.
output: The cause was an incorrectly set periodic registration timer on the AMF (and broadcast to UEs). It was configured to a value shorter than most UEs default behavior leading to mismatches. The resolution was to adjust the timer setting to a more appropriate (longer) duration that aligns with UE expectations and standards. After updating this configuration on the AMF and gNodeBs; UEs were no longer unexpectedly deregistered during idle periods. This prevented unnecessary session interruptions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Duplicate AMF ID in network configuration causing some UEs to attach to a wrong or conflicting AMF and leading to unstable connections. Due to a configuration oversight; two AMF instances were set with the same AMF identifier (AMF ID). This caused confusion in the network. Some UEs sometimes got handled by one AMF and then their follow-up messages got routed to the other which did not recognize them. Users experienced dropped connections or had to reattempt registration. Logs showed inconsistent assignment of UEs to AMFs and gNodeBs were unsure which AMF to target for certain UEs.
output: Once the duplication was discovered in the AMF IDs; the fix was to assign a unique identifier to each AMF as intended. Network configuration (both AMF and gNodeB settings) was updated to correct the IDs. After rectifying this; each UE consistently interacted with a single correct AMF instance. Stability returned to those connections. As a preventative measure; a configuration audit was implemented to flag duplicate IDs for any core network elements in the future.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Suboptimal message scheduling in AMF leading to delays in processing signals under high load. Under heavy load; it was noticed that less important management messages were being processed by the AMF while some registration messages were waiting. This led to a few UEs timing out on registration or session setup because their requests were queued behind lower priority tasks. Essentially; the AMF scheduling was not prioritizing certain NAS messages appropriately when resources were strained.
output: The team identified that the scheduling algorithm in the AMF did not prioritize initial attach or session setup messages over routine management tasks. A fix was applied in the form of a software update that adjusted the priority of different message types. After deploying this update; the AMF began processing registration and session establishment signals with higher priority during high load. Subsequent tests under load showed that procedures completed without undue delay and UEs no longer timed out waiting for service.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Partial network interface failure on AMF disconnecting a subset of gNodeBs and impacting UEs served by those nodes. Due to a hardware issue; one of the network interface cards (NICs) on the AMF failed. gNodeBs connected via that particular interface lost connectivity to the AMF while gNodeBs on other interfaces were unaffected. This resulted in a localized outage: UEs on the affected gNodeBs lost data service and could not register whereas other UEs continued normally.
output: Engineers quickly identified the interface card failure through hardware logs. The immediate action was to reroute the affected gNodeBs to a backup interface where possible. The faulty NIC was then replaced. After replacement and reconfiguration; the gNodeBs re-established their SCTP connections with the AMF. Service was restored to the impacted UEs. To avoid such issues; the AMF was configured with link redundancy so that if one interface fails traffic automatically shifts to another without interruption.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Overload control activation causing the AMF to intentionally delay or reject some UE requests to protect the system; this led to service access delays. During a period of extreme load; the AMF triggered its overload protection mechanism. This resulted in some UEs being told to wait (for example via a back-off timer in a reject message) or their non-urgent requests being temporarily rejected. While this protected the core from crashing; those UEs experienced delayed service until the load subsided. The behavior was observed in logs as overload control signals being sent.
output: Overload control kicking in indicated the system was running beyond its comfortable capacity. The resolution was twofold: operational and configuration. On the operational side; additional AMF capacity was brought online to share the load and the distribution of UEs was balanced. On the configuration side; threshold parameters for overload triggers were fine-tuned so that only truly necessary throttling would occur. After these steps; the AMF was able to handle the traffic without broadly delaying UE requests and the overload protection only engages in more extreme scenarios.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Emergency service attach misconfiguration preventing emergency call UEs from establishing the required data session for IMS emergency services. Emergency calls from 5G phones were not going through. When an emergency number was dialed; the phone tried to establish an emergency PDU session for IMS emergency services but it failed. The AMF logs show that the emergency registration was accepted but the subsequent setup of an emergency data session was rejected. Regular (non-emergency) services were unaffected.
output: Upon investigation; it was found that the AMF (and related network functions) were not configured with the proper APN (DNN) or slice for emergency services. The AMF did not know how to handle the emergency PDU session request. The fix involved configuring the network with the appropriate emergency session settings: a predefined emergency DNN and ensuring the AMF and SMF recognized emergency call requests. After updating the configuration; emergency calls established the necessary data session for IMS (VoLTE or VoNR emergency) and were completed successfully. The change was tested to ensure reliability of emergency services.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Temporary thread crash in AMF service causing some requests to fail until the thread auto-restarted; this led to intermittent service for a subset of UEs. A particular service thread within the AMF responsible for processing a certain subset of tasks (for example handling location updates or paging) was observed to crash occasionally under specific conditions. When it crashed; those specific tasks would fail or be delayed until the AMF automatically restarted the thread or process. UEs experienced issues like missing a page or having to retry a location update procedure; but the AMF as a whole did not go down.
output: Developers determined there was a code bug causing that thread to crash when it encountered an unusual sequence of events. The AMF had a built-in mechanism to restart the thread; which is why the impact was limited. For resolution; a patch was created to fix the bug in the thread code. In the meantime; operations put the AMF under increased monitoring to quickly react if the thread crash happened again. Once the patch was applied; the thread remained stable and UEs no longer experienced the intermittent issues. The resolution ensures that the particular sequence no longer triggers a crash.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: GUTI (temporary ID) collision issue leading to two UEs being confused for each other; one UE session was mistakenly affecting the other. In a rare case; two UEs were assigned identical 5G-GUTI (temporary identifiers) by the core due to an ID generation bug. As a result when one of those UEs tried to establish a session or update its registration the AMF overwrote the context of the other. This led to dropped connectivity for one UE and confusion in the network records. The issue was observed when logs showed an existing context being unexpectedly replaced during a new registration.
output: The root cause was a bug in the identifier allocation algorithm that did not properly avoid recently released IDs. The resolution was to fix the ID generation logic to ensure uniqueness even in rapid attach and detach scenarios. Engineers also manually cleared the conflicting contexts and forced both UEs to re-register to get new unique identifiers. After the fix; no further collisions occurred. The AMF was monitored for a period under high attach and detach churn to confirm the issue was resolved.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Policy control misconfiguration resulting in a certain group of subscribers being inadvertently blocked from data service. It was noticed that all users of a specific plan or category (for instance enterprise users or a specific APN) were not able to use data. They could register; but right after their session would be terminated by the network. AMF and SMF logs indicated that a policy decision was denying their session. This correlated with a recent policy update in the core.
output: The cause was a misconfigured policy rule in the PCF (Policy Control Function) or subscription database that flagged that subscriber group as not allowed data. The AMF and SMF were simply enforcing this incorrect policy. The fix involved correcting the policy rules in the PCF and UDM so that those subscribers are allowed the intended services. After updating the policy configuration; the AMF and SMF accepted the sessions for those users. They were then able to establish and maintain data connectivity. To ensure this does not recur; policy changes will undergo more rigorous testing including sample subscribers of each category.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Path MTU issue on N2 interface leading to larger NGAP messages being dropped and causing some session setups to fail. Certain procedures that involve larger NGAP messages (for example PDU Session Setup with many QoS rules or handover preparation messages) were failing. Traces showed that those messages never reached the AMF or were corrupted. However smaller messages were fine. This typically happened for UEs with lots of QoS parameters or when multiple PDU sessions were set up at once. The network path MTU between gNodeB and AMF was suspected.
output: The issue was tracked to an MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) misconfiguration on the transport network for the N2 interface. Large NGAP messages were getting fragmented and lost because the network did not handle the fragmentation properly. The resolution was to adjust the MTU settings on the relevant interfaces to ensure the N2 link could transmit large packets or allow fragmentation properly. Once the MTU was corrected; the large NGAP messages got through intact. Session setups and handovers that involve bigger messages succeeded. Post-fix testing included sending maximum size messages to verify no drops.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Routine maintenance task caused performance hitch leading to brief service slowdown as the AMF did a resource-intensive task at an inopportune time. During a busy period; the AMF suddenly experienced a spike in CPU and memory usage for a few minutes correlating with a slowdown in processing registrations and session setups. Some UEs experienced delayed responses or had to retry. It was found that a routine maintenance or backup task (like log compression or database cleanup) kicked in unexpectedly during peak hours.
output: The AMF was performing a maintenance function at a non-ideal time. The fix was to reschedule such tasks to off-peak hours and ensure that any on-demand heavy processes are coordinated with traffic patterns. In this case; the maintenance script schedule was adjusted. After rescheduling; subsequent busy hours did not see the performance hitch. Additionally; a one-time operation was done to clear any backlog so that future maintenance tasks would complete faster. UEs and services continued normally after the adjustment.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Authentication edge case from certain SIMs causing those UEs to take longer to attach due to an extra round of authentication. Subscribers using a particular SIM type (or operator) were taking much longer to attach. The attach would eventually succeed but only after retrying the authentication step. Logs indicated that the first authentication attempt for those SIMs returned an unexpected indication requiring a fallback procedure. This only affected a subset of UEs; others attached quickly.
output: This turned out to be an edge case where the AUSF and AMF had to fallback to a different authentication method for those SIMs (for example using 5G EAP-AKA fallback). The delay was because the AMF did not immediately try the alternate method. The resolution was to update the AMF authentication handling to recognize this SIM type and automatically use the appropriate method without a timeout. After the update; those UEs attached on the first attempt without delay. This improvement streamlined the process and logs confirmed that the extra retry was no longer occurring.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Internal AMF service monitoring agent crash triggering alarms but not affecting 5G data sessions for users. An internal monitoring or OAM (Operations and Maintenance) agent process within the AMF crashed. This process is responsible for reporting status and metrics to the management systems. While the crash did not impede user traffic or control plane operations; it did result in alarms and loss of visibility into the AMF status. Operations noticed the AMF stopped sending heartbeat or stats updates.
output: The resolution involved restarting the failed OAM agent on the AMF and applying a fix to prevent it from crashing on certain data. The team checked that no actual 5G service was impacted; this was purely an observability issue. After the agent was back; it resumed sending metrics and the alarms cleared. For a permanent fix; a patch from the vendor was applied to the OAM agent service. Meanwhile; the AMF itself had continued to handle calls so once monitoring was restored it was confirmed there were no lingering service issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF lacks support for new IoT device category causing those devices (like RedCap 5G UEs) to fail registration on the network. A batch of newly introduced IoT-oriented 5G devices (with reduced capability specifications) could not attach to the 5G core. Whenever these devices attempted to register; the procedure did not complete. The AMF logs show it received the initial NAS messages but then rejected them due to an unsupported capability error. Other regular 5G smartphones were unaffected highlighting that the issue was specific to this new device type.
output: It was determined that the AMF current software did not recognize some parameters or profiles of the new RedCap (Reduced Capability) devices. The resolution was to upgrade the AMF software to a version that supports this device category. The vendor patch enabled the AMF to handle the new capability information properly. After the upgrade; the IoT devices successfully registered and established data sessions. The deployment process now includes validating network support for any new device categories to prevent such issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Automatic failover to backup link ensuring continuity when the primary N2 link had a brief issue with negligible impact on service. The AMF primary N2 interface experienced a short disruption (for example; a momentary line error) but the AMF seamlessly switched to a secondary backup connection. Users did not notice any outage; though a few signaling messages had to be retransmitted. The event was logged by the system as a link failover occurrence.
output: This was handled by the network redundancy design. No action was needed from users. The technical team reviewed interface logs to confirm the automatic failover functioned correctly. The primary link was tested and brought back into service. Since the backup took over instantly; data service impact was negligible. The only follow-up was routine: replacing a suspect cable on the primary link as a precaution. The incident highlighted the effectiveness of having redundant paths for interfaces.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SNMP monitoring agent stopped causing an alarm for missing heartbeats but not affecting user data traffic. Network management systems reported that the AMF became unreachable via SNMP and stopped sending performance metrics. However; all 5G services continued normally for users. It appears the SNMP agent process on the AMF crashed or hung as other management protocols like ping were fine and subscribers were unaffected.
output: Operators restarted the SNMP monitoring agent on the AMF which restored the heartbeat and performance metric reporting. The cause was likely a bug in the SNMP agent. To prevent recurrence; a software update for the management agent was scheduled. This incident only impacted the monitoring capability and not the 5G data services. After the fix; the alarm cleared and the AMF status was fully visible to the network monitoring system again.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Older UEs require fallback procedure causing a slight delay in their connection but ultimately succeeding without user impact. A handful of older model 5G phones took a few seconds longer to complete registration and start data services. The AMF logs show that these devices initially attempted a now-deprecated cipher suite and got a security mode reject; then fell back to a supported one and continued normally. Users with those phones did not notice anything beyond perhaps a slightly slower connection setup.
output: No immediate action was required as the system already handled the fallback. The observation was noted and it was determined that it was due to legacy device behavior. As a fine-tuning measure; the network might consider disallowing the unsupported option upfront by configuration so that the negotiation happens faster. However; since the fallback worked and no service was denied; this remained a compatibility note. The devices continue to connect on the second attempt seamlessly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Optional parameter missing in gNB messages leading to benign warnings in AMF logs but no effect on data sessions. During interoperability testing; the AMF log raised warnings that an optional Information Element was not present in some NGAP messages from a gNodeB. This parameter was not and the AMF used default values in its absence. The data sessions and registration of UEs on that gNodeB were not affected; only the log contained warning entries.
output: The warnings were investigated and it was confirmed that the optional parameter (perhaps related to gNB configuration) was not needed for normal operation. The gNodeB was from a vendor that simply omits that IE. No change in functionality was required; however to clean up the logs and avoid confusion a software tweak on the AMF was scheduled to suppress or properly handle the missing optional parameter without warning. Service continued normally and this remained only a cosmetic issue.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Slow memory growth observed with routine maintenance preventing any impact on service. Over the span of several weeks; operators noticed that the AMF memory usage was creeping upward slowly; though no issues had occurred. The trend suggested a small memory leak in a non-part of the system. However; the AMF was regularly restarted during weekly maintenance windows which reset the memory usage each time before it became problematic. Users never experienced any fault from this.
output: The issue was and handled by existing maintenance procedures. Engineers did file a report with the vendor to patch the memory leak in a future update; but since the usage never approached dangerous levels between scheduled restarts there was no user impact. In the interim; they continued to monitor the memory trend. Eventually; a patch was applied during a maintenance window to plug the leak ensuring even over long runtimes the memory stayed stable.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: License server unreachable briefly triggering a grace period on the AMF but not interrupting service. For a short period; the AMF could not contact its license server or controller (network connectivity issue to the license service). The AMF raised an alert that it was operating on a grace license mode. During this grace period; all user services continued normally and users were unaware of any potential issue. The system has a built-in grace period to handle such temporary disconnects.
output: The situation resolved itself once the connectivity to the license server was restored. The AMF continued to function using its grace period with no degradation to user services. Administrators confirmed that the grace period was active and kept an eye on it; but since the connection came back well before the grace period lapsed no further action was necessary. They did however check the network connectivity to ensure the license server is reliably reachable in the future. The alarm about license connectivity was cleared automatically upon reconnection.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: hardware error on interface module corrected by error handling; this resulted in no noticeable service issues. One of the AMF interface modules (hardware card) reported a few correctable errors (like CRC errors on a fiber link). The system error correction mechanisms handled these; and the redundancy ensured data was resent if needed. There was no user-visible impact; though the hardware logs noted the event and raised a alarm for maintenance.
output: The maintenance team proactively replaced the suspect fiber transceiver after noticing an uptick in correctable errors. The AMF never lost connectivity on that interface; so sessions were unaffected. Post replacement; the error count stopped increasing. This was a precautionary fix to ensure the errors did not evolve into a issue. Service remained continuous throughout and the alarm was cleared after the hardware swap and testing.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Conflicting configuration entry resulting in a warning at startup but overridden by another setting with no service impact. When the AMF booted up after a configuration change; it logged a warning that two configuration entries overlapped or conflicted (for example duplicate entries for a parameter). The system by design chose one and ignored the other; proceeding with the effective configuration. 5G services ran normally; but the warning indicated a tidy-up was needed in the config files.
output: Engineers reviewed the configuration and removed the redundant entry to eliminate the warning. Since the AMF was already using the correct setting (the second entry was being ignored) there was no impact on service to begin with. This was purely a configuration cleanup. After the fix; the AMF started without any warnings. This ensured clarity in system logs and prevented any potential confusion from conflicting config entries all without any user-facing issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Preemptive config fix after audit addressing a potential fault before it could affect service. During a routine audit of the AMF configuration and logs; engineers spotted a parameter that was not set according to best practices (for example a timer value or threshold that was off by a small amount). Although this had not yet led to any incidents or noticeable problems; in extreme situations it might have caused a issue. No user had been affected and the network was operating normally.
output: As a precaution; the team decided to correct the parameter to the recommended value. The change was applied during a maintenance window even though it was not urgent. The fix ensured that the potential issue would never surface. Since the issue was caught preemptively; there was zero user impact. The AMF continued to perform normally and the audit was marked complete with all configurations validated against best practices.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF overloaded causing attach failures
output: This issue indicates that the AMF is overloaded or at full capacity. When the AMF is handling too much signaling traffic it may start dropping requests or timing out on UE registrations. As a result some devices cannot register or attach properly to the network. To resolve this monitor the load on the AMF and its resource usage. If it is overburdened consider balancing traffic by adding another AMF instance or increasing capacity. Also ensure the configuration is optimized. Restart or scale out the AMF if needed to reduce the load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF under heavy load leading to registration timeouts
output: This issue indicates that the AMF is overloaded or at full capacity. When the AMF is handling too much signaling traffic it may start dropping requests or timing out on UE registrations. As a result some devices cannot register or attach properly to the network. To resolve this monitor the load on the AMF and its resource usage. If it is overburdened consider balancing traffic by adding another AMF instance or increasing capacity. Also ensure the configuration is optimized. Restart or scale out the AMF if needed to reduce the load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF at capacity resulting in dropped connections
output: This issue indicates that the AMF is overloaded or at full capacity. When the AMF is handling too much signaling traffic it may start dropping requests or timing out on UE registrations. This can lead to the connection failures observed. To resolve this monitor the load on the AMF and its resource usage. If it is overburdened consider balancing traffic by adding another AMF instance or increasing capacity. Also ensure the configuration is optimized. Restart or scale out the AMF if needed to reduce the load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF overloaded with signaling causing slow response to registration
output: This issue indicates that the AMF is overloaded or at full capacity. When the AMF is handling too much signaling traffic it may start dropping requests or timing out on UE registrations. As a result some devices cannot register or attach properly to the network. To resolve this monitor the load on the AMF and its resource usage. If it is overburdened consider balancing traffic by adding another AMF instance or increasing capacity. Also ensure the configuration is optimized. Restart or scale out the AMF if needed to reduce the load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF experiencing high load leading to intermittent attach issues
output: This issue indicates that the AMF is overloaded or at full capacity. When the AMF is handling too much signaling traffic it may start dropping requests or timing out on UE registrations. As a result some devices cannot register or attach properly to the network. To resolve this monitor the load on the AMF and its resource usage. If it is overburdened consider balancing traffic by adding another AMF instance or increasing capacity. Also ensure the configuration is optimized. Restart or scale out the AMF if needed to reduce the load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF misconfigured and rejecting all registration attempts
output: This fault suggests a configuration error in the AMF. If the AMF is misconfigured (for example with incorrect PLMN or tracking area settings) it can reject or fail to process registration requests from UEs. The solution is to review the AMF configuration and correct any mistakes. Ensure that parameters like PLMN IDs tracking area codes and network identifiers match the rest of the network. After correcting the configuration the registration process should proceed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF configured with incorrect PLMN causing UE registration failures
output: This fault suggests a configuration error in the AMF. If the AMF is misconfigured (for example with incorrect PLMN or tracking area settings) it can reject or fail to process registration requests from UEs. The solution is to review the AMF configuration and correct any mistakes. Ensure that parameters like PLMN IDs tracking area codes and network identifiers match the rest of the network. After correcting the configuration the registration process should proceed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Misconfigured AMF leading to registration request rejections
output: This fault suggests a configuration error in the AMF. If the AMF is misconfigured (for example with incorrect PLMN or tracking area settings) it can reject or fail to process registration requests from UEs. The solution is to review the AMF configuration and correct any mistakes. Ensure that parameters like PLMN IDs tracking area codes and network identifiers match the rest of the network. After correcting the configuration the registration process should proceed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF rejecting registration requests due to configuration error
output: This fault suggests a configuration error in the AMF. If the AMF is misconfigured (for example with incorrect PLMN or tracking area settings) it can reject or fail to process registration requests from UEs. The solution is to review the AMF configuration and correct any mistakes. Ensure that parameters like PLMN IDs tracking area codes and network identifiers match the rest of the network. After correcting the configuration the registration process should proceed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF registration procedure failing because of a misconfiguration
output: This fault suggests a configuration error in the AMF. If the AMF is misconfigured (for example with incorrect PLMN or tracking area settings) it can reject or fail to process registration requests from UEs. The solution is to review the AMF configuration and correct any mistakes. Ensure that parameters like PLMN IDs tracking area codes and network identifiers match the rest of the network. After correcting the configuration the registration process should proceed normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF failing to authenticate subscribers
output: The AMF is experiencing authentication failures. This often occurs if the AMF cannot retrieve subscriber authentication data or if there is a mismatch in security credentials. It might be due to a communication issue with the UDM/AUSF or incorrect subscriber keys. To troubleshoot verify that the AMF can communicate with the UDM and AUSF. Check for any errors in retrieving subscriber profiles or authentication vectors. Ensure the subscriber credentials (like keys or SIM information) are correct and synchronized. Resolving any data mismatches or fixing network connectivity should restore proper authentication.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF lost connection to gNB causing service outage
output: The AMF is not communicating with the gNB which explains the service outage or registration failures. This can happen if the connection (N2 interface) between the gNB and AMF is down or blocked. Possible causes include network failures incorrect IP addressing or an SCTP link issue on the interface. To fix this check the connection between the gNB and AMF. Ensure that the SCTP link (N2) is established and not blocked by any firewall. Verify that the gNB is configured with the correct AMF address and that both endpoints can reach each other on the network. Once the communication is restored the registration requests should succeed.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF fails to update UE context during handover
output: This fault suggests a problem with how the AMF handles mobility or handover events. If the AMF fails to update the UE context or transfer data during a handover the session can drop. Such an issue might be caused by missing configuration for handover procedures or a software bug in the AMF mobility management. The troubleshooting steps include examining the AMF logs during the handover to see what went wrong. Ensure that all parameters for inter-AMF or intra-AMF handovers are configured correctly. If a software error is suspected update the AMF to the latest software version or patch. Proper configuration or patching should resolve the handover issue.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF cannot assign an SMF for new sessions
output: The AMF is having trouble assigning or communicating with an SMF for session management. This could happen if the AMF cannot find a suitable SMF for the requested session perhaps due to a network slice configuration issue or missing DNN information. It might also indicate that the AMF-SMF interface is misconfigured or the SMF is not registered properly in the core network. To resolve this verify that the NSSF is providing the correct slice and that an SMF is available for that slice. Check that the SMF is properly registered and discoverable (for example via the NRF) and that the AMF has the correct configuration to reach it. Correcting any configuration mismatches or registering the SMF properly should allow the AMF to forward session requests to the SMF.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF software bug causing periodic crashes
output: The AMF appears to be suffering from instability due to a software defect. Frequent crashes or memory leaks in the AMF software can cause service disruptions. This may be triggered by specific signaling scenarios or a known bug in the current software version. To address this analyze the AMF logs or crash dumps for error patterns. Check if there are known software updates or patches that fix this issue and apply them. In the meantime restarting the AMF might restore service temporarily but a software update or bug fix will be needed for a permanent resolution.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF configuration error causing incorrect message routing
output: An incorrect configuration in the AMF is likely causing abnormal behavior. When the AMF has a parameter set incorrectly or conflicting settings it can result in failures in call flow or message routing. This kind of fault might not be immediately obvious until a specific feature or scenario triggers it. The remedy is to thoroughly review the AMF configuration. Compare the settings against known good configurations or documentation to identify any incorrect values. Once the misconfigured parameter is corrected and the AMF is restarted (if necessary) the network issues should be resolved.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF user capacity exceeded and new devices cannot register
output: The AMF may have reached its capacity limits. If the AMF has a maximum number of subscribers or sessions it can handle (due to hardware limits or license restrictions) exceeding that limit will prevent new devices from registering. In this scenario the AMF is essentially out of resources for additional connections. To fix this check the AMF resource utilization and licensing status. If a limit has been reached you may need to increase the capacity by adding more resources or obtain a higher-capacity license. Additionally ensure that stale sessions or inactive users are cleared from the AMF so they do not consume capacity unnecessarily.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: AMF not connecting due to certificate mismatch
output: There seems to be a security configuration issue affecting the AMF connectivity. If the AMF is not connecting due to a certificate mismatch or TLS handshake error it means the secure communication between the AMF and another core component is failing. This could be caused by an expired certificate a trust configuration error or inconsistent security settings between the AMF and its peers. To resolve this verify the certificates and security settings on the AMF and the corresponding network function it is communicating with. Ensure that the AMF certificate is valid and trusted by its peers and that it trusts the peer certificates as well. Update any expired or incorrect certificates and align the TLS configurations on both sides. Once the certificate issue is fixed the AMF should be able to establish secure connections normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF fails to assign IP address to UE
output: The SMF is failing to allocate an IP address to the UE. This usually happens when the IP address pool is exhausted or not configured correctly. If the SMF has run out of available IPs or the requested IP type (IPv4 or IPv6) is not supported then the session establishment will fail. Check the IP pools configured on the SMF for the data network. Ensure there are free IP addresses available and that the pool matches the type of IP the UE is requesting. If the pool is empty extend the pool or release IPs from stale sessions. Correct any misconfiguration in the addressing setup and then attempt the session again.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF cannot reach UPF for session setup
output: There appears to be a communication failure between the SMF and the UPF. The SMF is not establishing the required PFCP session. This suggests it cannot reach or configure the UPF. This could be due to network connectivity issues such as an incorrect IP address or port. Another possibility is a misconfigured UPF address or incompatible PFCP settings. Verify connectivity between the SMF and UPF on the N4 interface. Confirm that the UPF is reachable at the configured IP address and that no firewall is blocking the PFCP port. Also check the SMF and UPF configurations to ensure they have matching PFCP versions and identifiers. The SMF should be able to establish the session with the UPF after connectivity and configuration issues are corrected.

This could be due to network connectivity issues such as an incorrect IP address or port. Another possibility is a misconfigured UPF address or incompatible PFCP settings. Verify connectivity between the SMF and UPF on the N4 interface. Confirm that the UPF is reachable at the configured IP address and that no firewall is blocking the PFCP port. Also check the SMF and UPF configurations to ensure they have matching PFCP versions and identifiers. The SMF should be able to establish the session with the UPF after connectivity and configuration issues are corrected.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF overloaded with too many sessions
output: The SMF may be overloaded with too many session requests. Under high load the SMF can become slow to respond or start dropping session setups. This often happens if the SMF CPU or memory resources are maxed out by a large number of concurrent sessions. Monitor the SMF resource usage during peak load. Consider scaling out by distributing sessions to another SMF instance or upgrading hardware if the SMF is at capacity. Optimizing the configuration or applying software updates could also help improve how the SMF handles heavy load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF does not recognize the requested DNN
output: The SMF is encountering a Data Network Name (DNN) issue. If the SMF does not recognize the DNN the UE is requesting it will reject the session. This can occur if the DNN is not configured on the SMF or if there is a typo or mismatch in the DNN configuration. Verify that the DNN (equivalent to an APN in 4G terms) requested by the UE is configured on the SMF. If not add the correct DNN configuration or have the UE use an available DNN. The SMF should accept the session once the configuration is updated if the DNN is valid for that subscriber.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF cannot get policy from PCF
output: The SMF is unable to retrieve the policy information from the PCF. This indicates a failure in communication between the SMF and PCF. The SMF did not receive the policy rules needed for the session. It could be that the PCF is down or unreachable or that it returned an error to the SMF. Check if the PCF is accessible and functioning properly. Ensure the SMF can reach the PCF over the network and that the PCF service is running without errors. If the PCF is down restore it. If it is running examine the logs on both the SMF and PCF for any errors. Fixing the connectivity or addressing any PCF errors will allow the SMF to obtain the necessary policy and proceed with session setup.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF missing subscriber data from UDM
output: The SMF might not have the necessary subscriber data for the session. The SMF may deny the session if it cannot retrieve the subscriber profile (such as allowed services or slice info) from the UDM. This could happen due to missing information in the subscriber profile or a communication error with the UDM. Check that the subscriber profile in the UDM contains all required information (for example allowed DNNs and QoS parameters). Verify that the SMF can query the UDM (or UDR) and is receiving the necessary data. If the subscriber data is incomplete update the profile in the UDM. Restoring proper subscriber information and connectivity should enable the SMF to set up the session.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF not releasing session after UE detach
output: There seems to be a problem with the SMF not clearing out old session information. A UE disconnect or detach should result in the SMF releasing the session resources. If the SMF fails to do so stale (ghost) sessions can remain and consume resources or cause conflicts. Examine the SMF logs for the session release procedures. Ensure that the SMF is receiving the session release signals from the AMF and that it responds appropriately. Consider applying a software update or patch if the SMF has a bug that leaves sessions hanging. You might need to manually clear any ghost sessions on the SMF to free up resources as a short-term solution.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF dropping session due to quota enforcement
output: The SMF is dropping or not establishing the session due to a policy or charging constraint. This likely means the PCF indicated the user has exceeded a data quota or is not authorized for more data. It could also be a miscommunication with the charging system leading the SMF to believe the user is out of credit. Check the subscription and usage status of the user in the policy control system. Determine if the user really exceeded their data quota or if this was a mistake. If it is a genuine quota enforcement then this behavior is by design. If it is an error ensure the PCF policy and charging data are correct. Adjust the subscriber policy or reset the quota if necessary and permitted. Attempt to re-establish the session after making these adjustments.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF fails to update session after handover
output: The SMF is failing to update the session during a mobility event such as a handover. A handover requires the SMF to update the user plane route to a new anchor point for the UE. The session continuity will break if the SMF cannot relocate the user plane or transfer the session context to a new anchor. Check how the SMF handles handover or relocation procedures. Verify that the SMF is receiving handover notifications from the AMF and that there is an available target UPF (new anchor) for the user plane. Correct any misconfiguration in mobility parameters. A patch or software update to the SMF may be required if the issue is due to a software limitation. The SMF should maintain session continuity across mobility events after proper configuration and updates.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: SMF process crash impacting data sessions
output: The SMF appears to be unstable or crashing. This is likely due to a software bug. Frequent SMF restarts or memory leaks will disrupt active sessions and prevent new sessions from establishing. This could be triggered by certain operations or simply a flaw in the current software version. Identify and address the software issue. Check the SMF logs or crash dumps for any error indicators or patterns. Consult the vendor for any available fixes or updates that address this bug. Restarting the SMF might temporarily restore service. A software patch or update will be needed for a long-term solution.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF not receiving user traffic from gNB
output: The UPF is not properly forwarding user-plane traffic between the device and the core network. This suggests a failure to establish the GTP-U tunnel on the N3 interface. The gNB and UPF are not successfully exchanging user packets. This might be due to a mismatched tunnel identifier or a network path issue. Check the GTP-U tunnel configuration between the gNB and the UPF. Ensure that the UPF has received the correct tunnel endpoint identifier and that the gNB is sending traffic to the UPF IP address on the expected port. Verify that no firewall or routing issue is blocking the N3 interface traffic. Correct any configuration mismatches and then reestablish the session so that user-plane packets flow normally.

Verify that no firewall or routing issue is blocking the N3 interface traffic. Correct any configuration mismatches and then reestablish the session so that user-plane packets flow normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF not forwarding data to data network
output: The UPF is not forwarding traffic to the external data network correctly. This usually indicates a routing or NAT configuration problem on the UPF. If the UPF lacks a proper route to the data network (internet) or if NAT is configured incorrectly then user traffic will not reach its destination. Verify the routing table and NAT settings on the UPF. Ensure that the UPF has a route to the data network and that any required NAT rules are in place. Check that the NAT function on the UPF is working correctly for user traffic (if the UPF is expected to perform address translation). Fix any missing routes or misconfigurations in NAT so that the UPF can forward traffic to the internet successfully.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF overloaded by heavy data traffic
output: The UPF appears to be overwhelmed by a high volume of traffic. When the UPF is overloaded it may start dropping packets or introducing high latency. This can occur if the throughput demand exceeds the UPF processing capacity or if its CPU usage is maxed out. Monitor the UPF CPU utilization and throughput statistics during peak traffic periods. If the UPF is running at capacity consider deploying additional UPF instances or upgrading the hardware to distribute the load. Also optimize the UPF configuration (for example adjust buffer sizes or thread counts) to improve how it handles heavy traffic. Reducing the load or increasing the UPF capacity will help prevent packet loss and performance issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF lost PFCP connection to SMF
output: The UPF has lost contact with its control plane (SMF) or failed to set up the session controls properly. Without an active PFCP session between the SMF and UPF the UPF will not have the rules to handle user traffic. This situation could result from a connectivity problem between the SMF and UPF or a configuration mismatch in PFCP parameters. Check the status of the PFCP session (N4 interface) between the SMF and the UPF. Ensure that the UPF is connected to the SMF and responding to PFCP heartbeats or requests. Look for any configuration mismatches such as incorrect IP addresses or PFCP port numbers on either side. Reestablish the control connection by correcting the configuration or restarting the PFCP session if necessary. This will allow the SMF to install the required rules on the UPF.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF not applying QoS rules
output: The UPF is not applying the expected Quality of Service rules. This might mean the UPF did not receive the QoS parameters from the SMF or PCF or a software issue is causing it to ignore them. All traffic might then be treated the same. This would affect users who require guaranteed bit rate or priority handling. Verify that the SMF (and PCF) sent the appropriate QoS rules to the UPF and that the UPF acknowledged them. Inspect the UPF configuration or logs to see if the QoS profiles were installed. If the QoS settings are present but not taking effect it could be a software bug. Try restarting the UPF or updating its software. Traffic should be prioritized as intended once the UPF is correctly enforcing the QoS rules.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF configuration error causing packet drop
output: A configuration error on the UPF is likely causing user traffic to be dropped. If the UPF has a wrong setting (for example a wrong interface IP or an incorrect forwarding rule) it can disrupt the data path. These kinds of misconfigurations may not be obvious until they start affecting traffic flow. Review the UPF configuration in detail. Check all relevant parameters such as interface IP addresses routing entries and forwarding policies for any mistakes or typos. Compare the UPF settings with the intended network design or a known good configuration to identify discrepancies. After correcting any configuration errors apply the changes and test again to ensure the UPF is forwarding traffic normally.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Inter-UPF communication failure on N9 interface
output: There is a failure in communication between multiple UPFs over the N9 interface. In a multi-UPF scenario (with an anchor UPF and a secondary UPF) traffic is not passing between them as expected. This often points to a misconfiguration of the N9 interface or missing routes between the UPFs. Check the configuration of the N9 interface on both the anchor and secondary UPF. Ensure that each UPF is configured with the correct peer address and that routing between the two is properly set up. Also verify that the N9 link is operational and not blocked by any firewall. Traffic should flow between the cascaded UPF nodes as intended once communication between the UPFs is correctly configured.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF network interface card failure causing packet loss
output: The UPF may be experiencing a hardware-related problem affecting packet forwarding. For instance a faulty network interface card or insufficient memory can cause the UPF to drop packets or perform poorly. Hardware malfunctions often lead to intermittent errors that impact throughput. Examine the system logs on the UPF for any hardware error indications (for example NIC driver errors or memory warnings). If a particular network interface is dropping packets then consider replacing that interface or updating its driver. Ensure that the server running the UPF has adequate CPU and memory resources and that there are no hardware component failures. Replacing or repairing faulty hardware and allocating sufficient resources should allow the UPF to return to normal operation.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: MTU mismatch causing packet drops at UPF
output: The UPF is likely dropping packets due to an MTU or fragmentation issue. Packets larger than the supported MTU might be discarded by the UPF if fragmentation is not handled properly. This can result in connectivity problems especially for large data transfers. Check the MTU settings on the UPF and along the path to the data network. Ensure that MTU values are consistent or that the UPF is configured to fragment packets when necessary. If there is an MTU mismatch adjust the MTU on the UPF or other network devices to a uniform value. Test with large packet sizes after aligning the MTU settings to confirm that the UPF no longer drops packets due to fragmentation issues.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UPF software bug causing service crashes
output: The UPF is behaving unreliably. This suggests a potential software bug. Symptoms such as the UPF process crashing or restarting indicate an internal error. It could be triggered by a known issue in the software (perhaps due to certain traffic patterns) or a memory leak that eventually causes a failure. Investigate the UPF logs and any crash dumps for clues about the failure. Check if there are known issues with the current software version and if so apply the recommended patches or updates. Restarting the UPF might temporarily restore service but a software update or configuration change is required for a permanent solution. After applying the fix monitor the UPF to ensure it remains stable under load.

input: UPF process crash leading to data outage
output: The UPF is behaving unreliably. This suggests a potential software bug. Symptoms such as the UPF process crashing or restarting indicate an internal error. It could be triggered by a known issue in the software (perhaps due to certain traffic patterns) or a memory leak that eventually causes a failure. Investigate the UPF logs and any crash dumps for clues about the failure. Check if there are known issues with the current software version and if so apply the recommended patches or updates. Restarting the UPF might temporarily restore service but a software update or configuration change is required for a permanent solution. After applying the fix monitor the UPF to ensure it remains stable under load.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM not responding to requests
output: The UDM is not responding to requests from other network functions. This suggests that the UDM service may be down or unreachable due to a network issue. Functions like the AMF cannot retrieve subscriber information or perform authentication when the UDM is offline or unreachable. Check the health and status of the UDM service. Ensure that the UDM application is running and that there is network connectivity between the UDM and other core network functions (like the AMF and AUSF). If the UDM process has stopped or crashed then restart it and observe if it begins responding to queries. Also verify that the UDM is properly registered in the network service registry (NRF) so that other components can discover it.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM missing subscriber data
output: The UDM does not have the required subscriber data available. This can occur if the subscriber is not provisioned in the UDM or if their profile information is incomplete. This means that requests for that subscriber data (such as authentication or service profile) are failing. Verify that the subscriber in question is properly provisioned in the UDM database. Check that all essential details (IMSI and subscription plan and allowed services) are present in the profile. If the profile is missing then create or update the subscriber record with the correct information. Once the subscriber data is in place the UDM will be able to supply the needed information to other network functions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM serving outdated subscriber data
output: The data in the UDM for some subscribers is outdated or not synchronized with the latest information. The UDM might be working with old subscription details. This can lead to mismatches when other services use updated data. One scenario is that recent changes to a subscriber profile (like a new service or updated credentials) were not applied to the UDM. Ensure that the subscriber profiles in the UDM have the latest information. If there is a separate provisioning system then make sure it has successfully updated the UDM with any recent changes. For example if a user changed plans or got a new SIM verify that the UDM reflects those updates. If it does not then manually synchronize or refresh the UDM data for those subscribers. Keeping the UDM data current will resolve mismatches due to outdated information.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM database error affecting queries
output: The UDM is experiencing an internal database error. If the UDM database has connectivity issues or has failed then the UDM cannot query or update subscriber information as needed. This situation causes errors when other network functions attempt to retrieve data like authentication vectors or subscription profiles. Examine the UDM internal logs for database connectivity or error messages. Ensure that the UDM can reach its data store (for instance the UDR or internal database). If there are replication issues or the database service is down then restore connectivity or restart the database service. Once the database is operational and accessible the UDM should resume handling requests properly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM indicates subscriber not authorized for service
output: The UDM is indicating that the subscriber is not authorized for the requested service. This could happen if the subscriber profile in the UDM has a restriction or barring on certain services or network access. For instance the user might be barred from data service due to a billing issue or an administrative block. The UDM then communicates this status to the network. Verify the subscriber profile in the UDM for any service restrictions or barred flags. If the user is not supposed to be barred update the profile to remove the restriction. Coordinate with the billing or policy systems to ensure that the user status is correct (for example confirm that any payment issues are resolved). After updating the subscriber authorization status in the UDM the network should allow the subscriber to use the data service if they are in good standing.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: Slice info mismatch between UDM and NSSF
output: There is an inconsistency in subscriber information between the UDM and other components like the NSSF or PCF. This can happen if the UDM lacks updated details that the NSSF or PCF expects such as permitted network slices or policy information for the subscriber. As a result when those components query the UDM they either get incorrect info or none leading to slice selection or policy application failures. Review the subscriber profile in the UDM for completeness regarding new features like network slicing and policy settings. Ensure that the allowed slice list for the subscriber (S-NSSAI information) is present and up to date if slice-based services are being used. Likewise verify that any policy-related data which the PCF might retrieve is correctly stored in the UDM. If discrepancies are found update the UDM records to match the intended configuration so that NSSF and PCF queries return consistent information.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM configuration error causing wrong data retrieval
output: A configuration error in the UDM is causing it to behave incorrectly. For example if the UDM is not configured to serve a specific PLMN or if there is a misconfiguration in its interface settings it may fail to respond correctly to certain requests. Such issues would manifest as UDM errors whenever that particular configuration is invoked. Review the configuration files or settings of the UDM. Look for obvious errors like incorrect PLMN IDs network identifiers or interface endpoints that the UDM uses to communicate with other functions. If the UDM is meant to handle multiple PLMNs or network slices ensure those are correctly configured in its settings. After fixing any configuration mistakes restart the UDM if necessary and test the request again to confirm that the UDM responds correctly.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM communication failing due to certificate issue
output: There appears to be a security or trust issue between the UDM and other network components. If the UDM does not trust the credentials or certificates from other services (or those services do not trust the UDM) secure communication will fail. This often occurs due to an expired certificate or a certificate mismatch or misconfigured security settings. This results in TLS handshake failures or rejected connections. Verify the certificates and security configurations on the UDM and the peer entities (such as the AMF or AUSF). Ensure that the UDM certificates are valid and not expired and that they are recognized as trusted by the other components. Likewise confirm that the UDM trusts the certificates of its peers. If any certificate is expired or untrusted then install a valid certificate and adjust the trust settings accordingly. Once the security settings are corrected the UDM should be able to communicate securely with other network functions.

instruction: As a 5G mobile network engineer resolve the following issues
input: UDM software bug causing service disruptions
output: The UDM is experiencing instability likely due to a software bug or glitch. Symptoms include the UDM process crashing or becoming unresponsive periodically. This behavior might be triggered by certain requests or load patterns that expose a flaw in the UDM software. Inspect the UDM logs around the times of the crashes or failures for any error messages or exceptions. Check if this is a known issue in the current version of the UDM software and consult the vendor or release notes for any available patches. In the short term restarting the UDM might restore service but the permanent fix will be to applyBelow is the CSV dataset of 300 records
